'''Richard Plunkett''' (1788-1832) was a Parish Officer of the Law, variously described as a [[headborough]], [[Beadle#Other uses|beadle]] or night-[[constable]], in [[Whitechapel]], in the [[East End of London]], between 1817 and 1826. His duties were centred upon the Whitechapel watch-house, from which he and his [[Watchman (law enforcement)#Watchmen in England|watchmen]] had to deal with nocturnal criminality in an area of rapidly increasing population, crowded conditions with poor sanitation, and much urban poverty and squalor. Plunkett's term of office just preceded the [[Metropolitan Police Act 1829]], by which a new system of policing was introduced. Plunkett was often called upon to give evidence at the [[Old Bailey]],<ref>''The Proceedings of the Old Bailey 1674-1913'', [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org Old Bailey online].</ref> the cases being scheduled for hearings two or three times a year. His testimony and that of his officers in these more serious cases show his relations with the population at large, his investigations, pursuits and arrests, often based on personal knowledge of the offenders. The majority of these cases resulted in convictions leading to [[penal transportation]]. His work illustrates the real activities of the parish police of Whitechapel just over a decade before the writing of ''[[Oliver Twist]]''.<ref>Charles Dickens, ''Oliver Twist; or, The Parish Boy's Progress'' (first book edition, Richard Bentley, London 1838): the arrest in Clerkenwell (Chapters X-XI); Whitechapel and Bethnal Green (Chapters XVIII-XIX, XXI).</ref>
==Background and family== Richard Plunkett was born, lived and died in Whitechapel. He was a son of Luke Plunkett and Margaret Read, who were married at [[Christ Church, Spitalfields]] in January 1772.<ref>Christ Church, Spitalfields, Register of Marriages, P93/CTC1/014 (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref> From various different homes in the neighbourhood, Luke and Margaret christened their children at [[St Mary Matfelon]], Whitechapel between 1776 (as of Bell Yard) and 1790 (as of Rosemary Lane, now Royal Mint Street).<ref>See an 1860 photograph of the old St Mary Matfelon at [http://www.middlesex-heraldry.org.uk/publications/monographs/mdxchurches/mdxchurches-whitechapelstmary.htm Middlesex Heraldry site].</ref> Richard was christened in April 1788 as of George Yard in Gunthorpe Street.<ref>St Mary, Whitechapel, Register of Baptisms, Oct 1774-May 1792, P93/MRY1/011 (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref>
Not much is known about Richard's childhood, but in February 1808, at Christchurch Spitalfields, he married Ann Haffner,<ref>Christ Church, Spitalfields, Register of Marriages, P93/CTC1/017 (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref> the middle of three daughters of Thomas Haffner and his wife Elizabeth Hunt.<ref>Married 10 April 1777: St Dunstan And All Saints, Register of Marriages, P93/DUN/044 (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref> Haffner lived at No. 2 Union Court, Fashion Street, and Richard Plunkett and his wife lived at No. 3 soon after their marriage. Fashion Street was just north of Keate Street and Thrawl Street, between [[Brick Lane]] and [[Commercial Street, London|Commercial Street]]. Plunkett was at that time clerk of a benefit society based at the Black Dog Inn in Church Street, [[Metropolitan Borough of Bethnal Green|Bethnal Green]],<ref>See 'Black Dog, Church Street, 101 Bethnal Green Road' [https://pubshistory.com/LondonPubs/BethnalGreen/BlackDog.shtml pubshistory.com].</ref> under management of Mr Stokes: Haffner, a member of the society, made Plunkett sole executor of his will (dividing his property between his three daughters), proved in June 1811.<ref>Will of Thomas Haffner of Spitalfield, Middlesex (P.C.C. 1811).</ref> Richard and Ann had four children, Richard James (1810), William (1812), Ann (1815) and Caroline (1817), all of whom were christened at St Mary's and survived infancy. Between 1812 and 1817 they were resident in Fieldgate Street, south of the [[Whitechapel Road]].<ref>St Mary, Whitechapel, Register of Baptisms, Jun 1792-Dec 1812, P93/MRY1/012 and (1813-), P93/MRY1/013 (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref>
In the same period his sister Mary had her own family. She married William Crowder, a stationer-bookbinder of [[Stepney (parish)|Stepney]], at Christ Church Spitalfields in May 1810,<ref>Christ Church, Spitalfields, Register of banns of marriage, P93/CTC1/041 (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref> and their first two daughters were christened from an address on [[London Wall]]. The next two, Elizabeth (1815) and Sarah (1817), were christened at St Mary Whitechapel as from Fieldgate Street;<ref>St Mary, Whitechapel, Register of Baptisms, P93/MRY1/013 (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref> later children were christened at the newly-rebuilt [[St Dunstan-in-the-East]], as from [[Mile End Old Town#Governance|Mile End Old Town]], or from [[Ratcliff]].<ref>St Dunstan and All Saints Stepney, Register of Baptisms (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref> All lived to be married.
==Plunkett's early cases== 1817 seems to mark the completion of Richard's family-making intentions for the time being, and his first appearance as 'constable of the night' at the [[Old Bailey]] relates to an incident just a month before his youngest daughter's christening. As he stood at the corner of Whitechapel church a 19-year-old man ran past an unemployed servant-girl and snatched the shawl (value 2 shillings) from her shoulders. Plunkett took him in charge, and the miscreant got 7 years' transportation.<ref> Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18170917-168&div=t18170917-168 Soloman Simpson, 17 September 1817].</ref>
As keeper of the watch-house Plunkett received whatever prisoners the watchmen brought in, and a charge of [[grand larceny]], with the same sentence, was successfully laid against Robert Miles the following April, when apprehended by two watchmen with a quantity of linen stolen from a carrier's wagon.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18180506-87&div=t18180506-87 Robert Miles, 6 May 1818].</ref> A month later Plunkett made his own arrest of a carpenter's lad carrying home a plank of wood from his workplace at 3.30 a.m. Searching the house, Plunkett found two doors which he had also taken. Here a verdict of Not Guilty was returned, the master having made no complaint.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18180617-141&div=t18180617-141 Daniel Hurley, 17 June 1818].</ref>
But in September 1818, following the wholesale theft of provisions (casks of butter and honey and a sackful of hams) from a warehouse in Goodman's Fields (an area around Leman Street and Alie Street), Plunkett, having taken one of the thieves prisoner, got information and went to his residence, where he recovered the goods from the man's wife and mother.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18180909-256&div=t18180909-256 Robert Wheelhouse, 9 September 1818].</ref> About the same time a 15-year-old boy who had stolen a tablecloth and 11 shillings in copper coins from his master, proprietor of an eating-house in Wentworth Street, was made by his father to give himself up to Plunkett. Both criminals were transported for 7 years.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18180909-285&div=t18180909-285 Alexander Flemming, 9 September 1818].</ref>
In a classic sting two years later, a young woman invited a printer of [[Coleman Street]], who frequented Whitechapel, back to her house. When he had got into bed and put his [[pocket watch]] under the pillow, she extinguished the light and ran off, and two people came in and ordered him out of the house. Missing his watch the man made Plunkett arrest the girl, but nothing was found. In court Plunkett said he thought the [[Plaintiff|complainant]] was drunk, and remarked that the man had accused him of stealing a [[Pound sterling|pound]] from him when held in charge two nights previously for drunkenness. The girl was found Not Guilty.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18200918-322&div=t18200918-322 Margaret Wall, 18 September 1820].</ref>
By contrast, in November 1820, a man was invited in by a girl in George Yard, Wentworth Street: once he had paid her something to fetch gin, first the women and then the men of the house robbed his money and possessions and forcibly ejected him, padlocking the door. The man called an officer, who arrested one of the girls (aged 17). Further complaint was made to Plunkett, who (having been born in George Yard) knew the man responsible and arrested him. Both were transported for life.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18201206-141&div=t18201206-141 Sarah Meyers and Emanuel Lyons, 6/15 December 1820].</ref>
==A dangerous occupation== Soon afterwards, on 16 January 1821, Plunkett faced a personal challenge. Now living at No. 5 Baker's Row (on the north side of Whitechapel High Street, just east of the [[Workhouse]]: now Vallance Road<ref>See map detail, Whitechapel, in [http://www.workhouses.org.uk/Whitechapel/ The Workhouse, the story of an institution] website.</ref>), his two sons usually closed the outer shutters of the windows on their return from school, but were delayed. Soon after 5 pm, while taking tea in his back room, he heard a noise and found that two men had broken into his house via the front window, and were moving about in the dark. Discovered, one jumped onto a table and out through the upper part of the sash. The other followed, his [[Gaiters|gaiter]] slipping from Plunkett's grasp. But Plunkett jumped after him, caught him, and gave him into charge of George Brock, who was standing by.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18210214-57&div=t18210214-57 William Haynes and William Harrison, 14 February 1821].</ref>
He then chased the other, whom he recognised, up Baker's Row and round the corner into Church Street, where the man appeared nonchalantly in the doorway of a public house. A fight ensued, and Plunkett took him. The two were found guilty of [[Burglary in English law|burglary]] and sentenced to death, but a [[Verdict#Special verdict|special verdict]] was returned pending a decision as to whether the window had been secured.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=o18210912-1-defend2124&div=o18210912-1 Supplementary material: Haynes & Harrison, 12 September 1821].</ref> (This case established that the pulling down of the sash of a window, though unfastened, constituted a [[Burglary#Common law definition|breaking]] within the definition of "breaking and entering".<ref>'Rex v. William Haines and William Harrison', W.O. Russell and E. Ryan, ''Crown Cases Reserved for Consideration: and Decided by the Twelve Judges of England from the Year 1799 to the Year 1824'' (Joseph Butterworth and Son, London 1825), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=BEhfAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA451#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 451-52]. (Google)</ref>) William Haynes and William Harrison were transported for life on the second [[Convict ship|convict voyage]] of the ''[[Asia (1818 ship)|Asia]]'' on 1 April 1822.<ref>Transported convicts - 258, [http://oldbritishnews.com/convicts/index.php/transported_convicts-258/ Old British News website].</ref>
Mary Crowder, Plunkett's sister, also found herself in the Old Bailey in the winter of 1820-21. She was still living at Greenfield Street, and in mid-February her lodger, who had been with her since mid-December, disappeared owing her 24 shillings. Some spoons and a pair of ear-rings went missing at the same time. She had not threatened to arrest him for the money owing: the apparent theft came to court, but was not proved against the defendant.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18210411-24&div=t18210411-24 Hertzig Brandham, 11 April 1821].</ref>
In June 1821 Plunkett testified in two cases of pocket-picking, one of which had taken him back to George Yard.<ref>Old Bailey Online, 6 June 1821: [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18210606-166&div=t18210606-166 Robert Lloyd]; [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18210606-167&div=t18210606-167 Henry Copas].</ref> In September two women who had accosted a man walking home at 2 a.m. and had taken 27 shillings from him were sentenced to transportation for life.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18210912-159&div=t18210912-159 Catherine Sullivan and Catherine Bryan, 12 September 1821].</ref> A year later Plunkett and his colleague John Clark went after two women known to them who were accused of stealing a coat and 35 [[Sovereign (English coin)|sovereigns]] from a retired excise-officer in the street, but although the coat was found the court had doubt of their guilt.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18220911-24&div=t18220911-24 Hannah Stanton and Esther Cummins, 11 September 1822].</ref> On the same day he gave evidence in a case of street robbery (classed as [[highway robbery]] with violence, though the work of a [[footpad]]) which led to a death sentence.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18220911-229&div=t18220911-229 Samuel Greenwood, 11 September 1822].</ref> Between December 1822 (when on one occasion he held an [[identification parade]]<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18230115-97&div=t18230115-97 Edmund Law and Thomas Webb, 15 January 1823].</ref>) and February 1825 Plunkett testified in nine other serious cases, mostly resulting in transportation.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18221204-155&div=t18221204-155 Philip Redman, 4 December 1822]; [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18221204-173&div=t18221204-173 John Archer and Ann Bradshaw, 4 December 1822]; [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18230219-137&div=t18230219-137 Daniel Griffiths, 19 February 1823]; [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18230409-2&div=t18230409-2 Mary Smith, 9 April 1823]; [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18230409-88&div=t18230409-88 Charles Wasen, 9 April 1823] (see also [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18210912-155&div=t18210912-155 12 September 1821]); [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18240715-92&div=t18240715-92 John Andrews, 15 July 1824]; [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18240916-137&div=t18240916-137 William Sparks, 16 September 1824]; [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18250217-100&div=t18250217-100 Thomas Scott, 17 February 1825].</ref>
==His last cases, and retirement== It happened that near to his house in Baker's Row stood the premises of Messrs. [[Brocks Fireworks]] factory. On 4 September 1825 two boys were engaged in ramming gunpowder into [[Firecracker|squibs]] when a spark ignited and the boys ran out in fright, throwing the firework aside. Fifty pounds of gunpowder and a large amount of [[saltpetre]] suddenly exploded, blowing the roof off, setting fire to the building, and smashing every pane of glass in most of the adjoining streets. "Females were frightened into [[Hysteria|hysterics]]" (runs the report), but the only serious injury was to Richard Plunkett's sister.<ref>'Dreadful Explosion', [[James Henry Leigh Hunt|Leigh Hunt]] (ed.), ''The Examiner'' 1825 (John Hunt, London), [https://books.google.com/books?id=8nMAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA566&lpg=PA566 p. 566]. (Google)</ref>
In November 1825 a respectable lady, Mrs Byrne, stopped at a house in Leman Street and remonstrated with the owner, an undertaker, who was beating his wife. The man then produced a constable's [[Baton (law enforcement)#History|baton]] and had Mrs Byrne sent to the watch-house as a [[common prostitute]]. Plunkett kept her there for two hours among some rough company, and was about to lock her in a cell when her husband and brother arrived to rescue her. She was vindicated in court, severe criticism was levelled against the watch-houses, and the wife-beating constable was arrested and charged.<ref>'Police - Lambeth Street', ''The Examiner'' 1825 (John Hunt, London), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8nMAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA747#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 747]. (Google)</ref>
In the same week a respectable-looking young man was found lying drunk on Whitechapel Road. The watchman took him to the watch-house to sleep it off, but when Plunkett looked in on him at about 4 a.m. he found him weltering in blood, having stabbed himself in the neck with a penknife. With immediate attention he was able to explain that he wished to end his life, and when further recovered was sent home in a [[Cabriolet (carriage)|cab]] under medical supervision.<ref>'Accidents, Offences, &c. - Attempted Suicide', ''The Examiner'' 1825 (John Hunt, London), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8nMAAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA748#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 748]. (Google)</ref>
These events doubtless contributed to Plunkett's retirement as beadle, and the evidence he gave leading to two further convictions in 1826 are his last recorded in the Proceedings of the Old Bailey.<ref>Old Bailey Online, [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18260406-85&div=t18260406-85 William Weir, 6 April 1826]; [https://www.oldbaileyonline.org/browse.jsp?id=t18260622-102&div=t18260622-102 John Peachey, 22 June 1826].</ref> At the time of the firework explosion his occupation is given as "writing ink maker", and in that capacity he took out insurance in December 1825.<ref>Ref. MS 11986/506/1039789 (Guildhall Library/LMA).</ref> By March 1827 he had become the publican of the Green Man in Castle Street, Whitechapel.<ref>Ref. MS 11936/506/1057848-849 (Guildhall Library/LMA).</ref> He was buried as from Castle Street at St Mary's Whitechapel on 10 June 1832, aged 44,<ref>St Mary, Whitechapel, Register of Burials, 12 June 1832 (London Metropolitan Archives).</ref> perhaps a victim of the [[1829-51 cholera pandemic|cholera epidemic]].<ref>R. McR. Higgins, 'The 1832 cholera epidemic in East London', "East London Record" 2 (1979), [http://www.mernick.org.uk/thhol/1832chol.html (mernick.org)].</ref> At her marriage in 1838 his daughter Ann recorded her late father's occupation as "publican".<ref>28 April 1838: Holy Trinity Minories, Register of Marriages, 1837 - 1860, P69/TRI2/A/01/Ms 9246/4 (Guildhall/LMA).</ref>

'''Rolando V. de la Rosa''', [[Dominican Order|O.P.]], is the ''Rector Magnificus'' (president) of the [[Pontifical University of St. Thomas Aquinas]] in Rome, as of 1 September 2016.
Formerly, he served as the [[Rector Magnificus of the University of Santo Tomas]] (UST), the oldest and the largest [[Catholic]] university in Asia. A religious leader and a seasoned educator, he was appointed by ''then'' [[President of the Philippines|Philippine President]] [[Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo]] as the Chairman of the [[Commission on Higher Education (Philippines)|Commission on Higher Education]] in 2004.<ref name="rosa">[http://www.ust.edu.ph/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=599&Itemid=108 UST Installs Fr. Rolando de la Rosa, OP, 95th Rector] ''University of Santo Tomas Website'' May 11, 2012</ref><ref name=mb>[http://www.articlearchives.com/education-training/education-systems-institutions/559354-1.html Father Rolando V. de la Rosa, OP: New Chairman of the Commission on Higher Education] ''Manila Bulletin Website'' May 11, 2012</ref>
==Early years and education== de la Rosa was born on June 27, 1953, in [[Manila]] where he spent his childhood. He completed his basic education courses at the [[Aquinas University]] in Rawis, Legazpi City, studied AB Philosophy and graduated Magna cum Laude from the [[Dominican House of Studies]].<ref name="rosa"/> He also graduated Magna cum Laude from the University of Santo Tomas with a degree in Bachelor of Sacred Theology in 1980. He was ordained priest in the [[Dominican Order]] on April 3, 1982.<ref name="rosa"/>
In 1984, Fr. de la Rosa earned his Licentiate in Sacred Theology degree, Magna cum Laude and Master of Arts in Higher Religious Studies, Summa cum Laude, both from UST. In the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] in [[Belgium]], he completed the Doctoral degrees graduating Magna cum Laude in two programs: Higher Religious Studies and Sacred Theology in 1988.<ref name="rosa"/>
==Career== He served his first two terms as Rector of the University of Santo Tomas for eight years, from 1990 to 1998. His aims as rector and president were to develop the university's research capabilities, and expand their outreach programs for community service. He established the Research and Endowment Foundation Incorporated to generate funds to finance continuing research activities in the university. Through this foundation, he was able to generate enough funds to establish the Thomas Aquinas Research Complex that houses today the various research centers in the university as well as the Graduate School. To strengthen and expand the community outreach programs of the university, he established the Office for Community Development which later evolved into the UST SIMBAHAYAN, the umbrella project for all university outreach programs focused on five K's: Karunungan (Knowledge transfer), Kalusugan (Medical missions), Kabuhayan (livelihood projects), Kanlungan (housing projects for the poor and those affected by natural disasters), and Kapayapaan (peace education for communities torn by religious and other conflicts.
As Rector, he became president of the Association of Catholic Universities of the Philippines and a two-time President of the ICUSTA [[International Council of Universities of Saint Thomas Aquinas]]. He was the founding president of the DOMNET (Network of Dominican Schools, Colleges and Universities in the Philippines) in 1995. He was chair of the Organizing Committee of the International Youth Forum for the [[World Youth Day 1995|World Youth Day in 1995]].<ref name="varsi">[http://www.varsitarian.net/news/de_la_rosa_elected_rector De la Rosa elected Rector] ''The Varsitarian Website'' May 11, 2012</ref>
He held various positions in the Dominican Province of the Philippines like Master of Novices, Diffinitor of the Provincial Chapter, Provincial Councilor, as well as Rector of the [[Colegio de San Juan de Letran#Colegio de San Juan de Letran - Calamba|Colegio de San Juan de Letran Calamba]].<ref name=mb/>
In 2008, he was again appointed by the Master of the Dominican Order as Rector Magnificus of the University of Santo Tomas (2008–2012).<ref name="varsi"/>
He had received numerous awards for his professional and civic achievements, like the National Book Award in History, the Catholic Authors Award, the Outstanding Manilan Award (1995 and 2011), Kyung Hee University (Korea) Medal of Highest Honor, and the 2012 Outstanding CEO Award in Education.
Fr. de la Rosa has written hundreds of articles and scholarly treatises, some of which has been translated into German and French, or anthologized in international publications. His book "Beginnings of the Filipino Dominicans" won the National Book Award in History in 1991.

{{For|the band|Sade (band)}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Sade | honorific_suffix = {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|commas=on|CBE}} | image = Sade Adu 1.jpg | caption = Sade performing at the [[SAP Arena]],
[[Mannheim]], [[Germany]], in 2011 | birth_name = Helen Folasade Adu | alias = Sade Adu | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1959|01|16|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Ibadan]], [[Colony and Protectorate of Nigeria]] | residence = [[Cotswolds]], [[Gloucestershire]], England | alma_mater = [[Saint Martin's School of Art]] | occupation = {{flatlist| *Singer *songwriter *actress }} | years_active = 1982–present | net_worth = £50 million (2015){{cite news|title=The Sunday Times Rich List 2015|url=http://features.thesundaytimes.co.uk/richlist/2015/live/richlist/view/group93/50/source/asc/|accessdate=15 September 2015|work=The Sunday Times}} | spouse = Carlos Pliego (m. 1989–1995) | partner = Ian Watts (2007–present) | children = 1 | website = {{URL|http://www.sade.com}} | module = {{Infobox musical artist | embed = yes | background = solo_singer | instrument = Vocals | genre = {{flatlist| *[[Jazz]] *[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] *[[soul music|soul]]}} | label = {{flatlist| *[[Portrait Records|Portrait]] *[[Epic Records|Epic]] *[[RCA Records|RCA]] *[[Sony Music UK|Sony]]}} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| *[[Sade (band)|Sade]]}} }}}} '''Helen Folasade Adu''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|size=100%|commas=on|CBE}} ({{lang-yo|Fọláṣadé Adú}} {{IPA-yo|fɔ̄láʃādé ādú|}}; born 16 January 1959), known professionally as '''Sade Adu''' or simply '''Sade''' ({{IPAc-en|ʃ|ɑː|ˈ|d|eɪ}} {{respell|shah|DAY|'}}), is a British Nigerian singer, songwriter, and actress. Born in [[Ibadan]], [[Nigeria]], Sade gained modest recognition as a fashion designer and part-time model, prior to joining the band Pride in the early 1980s. After gaining attention as a performer, she formed the band Sade, and secured a recording contract with [[Epic Records]] in 1983. The band then released the album ''[[Diamond Life]]'' a year later, which became one of the best selling albums of the era, and the best-selling debut ever by a British female vocalist. It also gained widespread critical acclaim and is largely considered [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|one of the best albums of all-time]]. Soon after, they released ''[[Promise (Sade album)|Promise]]'' (1985), which was also a resounding critical and commercial success, becoming the band's first album to debut atop the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. It later earned quadruple platinum certification in the U.S., and reached platinum across Europe. It also earned the group the [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist]] in 1986. Their following two releases, 1988's ''[[Stronger Than Pride]]'' and 1992's ''[[Love Deluxe]]'', were also critically and commercially successful; however, the band would go on hiatus after the birth of Sade's son, Andes the singer would experience widespread media coverage during the period for unsubstantiated claims of [[Major depressive disorder|mental health]] and [[addiction]] issues. After a spell of eight years without an album, which came after Sade appeared in the film ''[[Absolute Beginners (film)|Absolute Beginners]]'' (1986), the band reunited in 1999, and released ''[[Lovers Rock (Sade album)|Lovers Rock]]'' in 2000. The album departed from the jazz-inspired inflections of their previous work, featuring more mellow sounds and pop compositions, and was critically praised, earning the group the [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album]]. The band would then undergo another term of hiatus, not producing music for another ten years until the release of ''[[Soldier of Love (album)|Soldier of Love]]''. The album was another commercial success, although critical reception remained divided, but won the group the [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]]. Following the album's release, the band entered a third period of hiatus, and have only released one new song (2018's "Flower of The Universe" for the soundtrack of Disney's "A Wrinkle In Time.") to date.https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2018/03/07/you-can-now-listen-to-sades-first-new-song-in-seven-years-flower-of-the-universe/?noredirect=on Sade is widely considered a musical influence, and her contributions to music have made her a global figure in popular culture for over two decades. She has been credited as one of the most successful British female artists in history,{{cite web|last=Sandall|first=Robert|title=Sade Emerges from Her Own Country Retreat |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/sade-emerges-from-her-country-retreat-h70c0x3v32r|work=[[The Sunday Times]]|date=31 January 2010|accessdate=2 September 2015}} and her work is listed among the finest in modern jazz history.{{cite web|title=The 100 Greatest Women In Music|url=http://www.vh1.com/news/1238/the-100-greatest-women-in-music/|website=VH-1+Music|publisher=Viacom International Inc.|accessdate=19 December 2012|date=13 February 2012}} Her services to music were also commemorated after being awarded the [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] chivalry honour in 2002. ==Early life== Helen Folasade Adu was born on 16 January 1959 in [[Ibadan]], [[Oyo State]], Nigeria. Her middle name, Folasade, means "honour confers a crown".{{cite book|last1=Eby|first1=Margaret|title=Rock and Roll Baby Names: Over 2,000 Music-Inspired Names, from Alison to Ziggy|date=2012|publisher=Gotham Books|location=New York|isbn=9781101561539|page=277|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TpxRTlukdxgC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}} Her parents are Adebisi Adu, a [[Nigerians|Nigerian]] lecturer in economics of [[Yoruba people|Yoruba]] background, and Anne Hayes, an [[English people|English]] district nurse; they met in [[London]], married in 1955, and moved to Nigeria.{{cite news|last1=Scott|first1=Paul|title=Britain's Smooth Operator from the 80s Who's Outselling Adele in America (Despite Living as a Recluse in the Cotswolds)|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2114712/Sade-outselling-Adele-America-despite-living-recluse-Cotswolds.html|accessdate=25 November 2014|work=Daily Mail|date=13 March 2012}} When Sade was four years old, her parents separated. Anne Hayes then returned to England, taking Sade and older brother Banji with her to live with their grandparents near [[Colchester]], Essex.{{cite web|title=Biog|url=https://www.sade.com/gb/biography/|website=www.sade.com|publisher=Sony Music Entertainment UK|accessdate=12 September 2015}} When Sade was 11 years old, she moved to [[Holland-on-Sea]], Essex, to live with her mother.{{cite news|last1=Berens|first1=Jessica|title=Sade|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9ugCQfxwym0C&pg=PA12&dq=spin+magazine+1985+Sade#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=21 August 2010|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|page=12|date=May 1985}} After completing her education at [[Clacton County High School]] at age 18, she moved to London and studied fashion design at [[Saint Martin's School of Art]].{{cite news|title=Sade’s First Album in 10 Years|url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/4861519.Sade___s_first_album_in_10_years/|accessdate=31 August 2015|newspaper=[[The Daily Gazette]]|date=20 January 2010}} ==Career== ===1980–84: Beginnings and ''Diamond Life''=== After completing a three-year course work in fashion design, and later modeling briefly, Sade began backup singing with British band Pride. During this time, she formed a songwriting partnership with Pride's guitarist/saxophonist [[Stuart Matthewman]]; together, backed by Pride's rhythm section, they began doing their own sets at Pride gigs. Her solo performances of the song "[[Smooth Operator]]" attracted the attention of record companies, and in 1983 Sade and Matthewman split from Pride, along with keyboardist Andrew Hale, bassist [[Paul Denman]] and drummer Paul Cook, to form the band Sade.{{cite web|title=Sade|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/artists/sade/biography|publisher=Rolling Stone|accessdate=3 March 2015}} By the time she performed her first show at London's [[Heaven (nightclub)|Heaven]] nightclub, she had become so popular that 1,000 people were turned away at the door. In May 1983, Sade performed their first US show at the [[Danceteria]] nightclub in New York City. On 18 October 1983, Sade Adu signed with Epic Records, while the rest of the band signed in 1984.{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/music/Sade/+wiki|title=Sade|work=Last.fm}} Following the record deal, the group began recording their debut album, ''[[Diamond Life]],'' which took six weeks to record and was recorded entirely at The Power Plant in London.{{cite news|url=http://www.redbullmusicacademy.com/magazine/key-tracks-sade-diamond-life|title=Recording|publisher=Red Bull Music Academy|date=|accessdate=3 March 2015}} ''Diamond Life'' was released on 16 July 1984, reached number two in the [[UK Album Chart]], sold over 1.2 million copies in the UK, and won the [[Brit Award]] for Best British Album in 1985.{{cite web|title=The BRITs 1985|url=http://www.brits.co.uk/history/shows/1985|website=BRIT Awards|accessdate=2 September 2015}} The album was also a hit internationally, reaching number one in several countries and the top ten in the US, where it has sold in excess of four million copies. ''Diamond Life'' had international sales of over six million copies, becoming one of the top-selling debut recordings of the '80s, and the best-selling debut ever by a British female vocalist. "[[Your Love Is King]]" was released as the album's lead single on 25 February 1984 and was a success in European territories, charting at number seven in Ireland and number six on the [[UK Singles Chart]].{{cite web |url=http://www.irishcharts.ie/search/placement |title=The Irish Charts |accessdate=2009-01-08 |work=[[Irish Recorded Music Association|IRMA]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/21427/sade/|title=Official Charts – Sade – Your Love Is King|accessdate=2 September 2015|work=Official Charts}} The song was less successful in the US, where it peaked at number 54 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]].{{cite news|title=Hot 100 Singles – Your Love Is King|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8CMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT61&lpg=PT61&dq=billboard+100+%22your+love+is+king%22&source=bl&ots=kF_0QDg1KM&sig=M8ffdUSZSC7m8IzuZCFmyyngABk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDYQ6AEwBWoVChMI75rdp-DXxwIVCpINCh1emw7Z#v=onepage&q=billboard%20100%20%22your%20love%20is%20king%22&f=false|accessdate=2 September 2015|work=Billboard|date=27 Jul 1985|page=62}} The third single, "[[Smooth Operator]]", was released on 15 September 1984 and became the most successful song in the US from the album ''Diamond Life''. The track peaked at number five on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and the US ''Billboard'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs|Hot Black Singles]], as well as peaking at number one on the US ''Billboard'' [[Hot Adult Contemporary Tracks|Adult Contemporary chart]].{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/sade-mn0000279337/awards |title=Sade > Charts & Awards > Billboard Singles |accessdate=8 January 2009|work=[[AllMusic]]}} In Europe the song fared well, peaking at number 19 in the UK,{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/21427/sade/|title=Official Charts – Sade – Smooth Operator|accessdate=2 September 2015|work=Official Charts}} and reaching the top 20 in [[Ö3 Austria Top 40|Austria]], Switzerland, France and Germany.{{cite web |url=http://swisscharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Sade&titel=Smooth+Operator&cat=s |title=Sade – Smooth Operator – Swisscharts.com |accessdate=9 January 2009 |work=SwissCharts.com}} ===1985–2000: Continued success and first hiatus=== In late 1985, the band released their second album, ''[[Promise (Sade album)|Promise]]'', which peaked at number one in both the UK and the US{{cite book|last1=Roberts|first1=David|title=British Hit Singles & Albums|date=2006|publisher=Guinness World Records|location=London|isbn=9781904994107}}{{cite book|last1=Whitburn|first1=Joel|title=The Billboard Book of Top 40 Hits, 9th Edition: Complete Chart Information about America's Most Popular Songs and Artists, 1955–2009|date=2012|publisher=Billboard Books|isbn=9780307985125|pages=556, 796, 801}} and became the band's first album to reach number one on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]. The album topped the chart in 1986 and spent two weeks at the peak position. Eventually, the album went on to sell four million copies in the region and was certified four times platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA).{{cite web|url=http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=2&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=&artist=Sade&format=ALBUM&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2010&sort=Artist&perPage=25|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130201070612/http://riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=2&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=&artist=Sade&format=ALBUM&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2010&sort=Artist&perPage=25|dead-url=yes|archive-date=1 February 2013|title=RIAA – Gold & Platinum – February 17, 2010: Sade certified album|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|accessdate=17 February 2010}} The album spawned two singles "[[Never as Good as the First Time]]" and "[[The Sweetest Taboo]]," the latter of which was released as the album's lead single and stayed on the US Hot 100 for six months.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/sade/biography/|title=Sade Bio – Sade Career|work=MTV Artists}} "The Sweetest Taboo" peaked at number five on the US ''Billboard'' Hot 100, number one on the US adult Contemporary chart, and number three on the US Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Singles & Tracks.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/promise-mw0000195597/awards|title=Promise – Sade – Awards – AllMusic|work=AllMusic}} Sade was so popular that some radio stations reinstated the '70s practice of playing album tracks, adding "Is It a Crime" and "Tar Baby" to their playlists. The following year, 1986, the band won a [[Grammy Award]] for [[Best New Artist]].{{cite web|title=And The GRAMMY Went To ... Sade|url=http://www.grammy.com/news/and-the-grammy-went-to%E2%80%A6-sade|website=GRAMMY.com|publisher=The Recording Academy|accessdate=12 September 2015|date=23 February 2011}} In 1986, Sade made her acting debut in ''[[Absolute Beginners (film)|Absolute Beginners]]'', a film adapted from the [[Colin MacInnes]] book of the [[Absolute Beginners (novel)|same name]] about life in late-1950s [[London]]. Sade played the role of Athene Duncannon and lent her vocals to the film's accompanying soundtrack.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090585/|title=Absolute Beginners (1986)|date=18 April 1986|work=IMDb}} The film was screened out of competition at the [[1986 Cannes Film Festival]] and grossed £1.8 million in the UK.{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/840/year/1986.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Absolute Beginners |accessdate=2009-07-17|work=festival-cannes.com}} Sade's third album, ''[[Stronger Than Pride]]'', was released on 3 May 1988, and like Sade's previous album became a commercial success and certified three times platinum in the US. The album was popularized by four singles, most notably the album's second single "[[Paradise (Sade song)|Paradise]]", which peaked at number 16 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and peaked at number one on the US ''Billboard'' [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]], becoming the band's first single to do so.{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/stronger-than-pride-mw0000651898/awards |title=Stronger Than Pride > Awards > Billboard Singles |accessdate=22 February 2009|work=[[AllMusic]]}} ''[[Love Deluxe]]'' was released as the band's fourth studio album on 26 October 1992. The album peaked at number three on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]]{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/love-deluxe-mw0000616233/awards |title=Love Deluxe > Awards > Billboard Albums |work=AllMusic |accessdate=31 March 2014}} and has sold 3.4 million copies in the United States.{{cite news|last1=Caulfield|first1=Keith|title=Ask Billboard: Keith Caulfield Answers Readers' Questions about Shania Twain, Mya, and Sade|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/71199/ask-billboard|accessdate=12 September 2015|work=Billboard|date=7 May 2003}} The album was later certified four times platinum by the RIAA for shipments of four million copies.{{cite web|url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?artist=%22Love+Deluxe%22|title=RIAA – Gold & Platinum Searchable Database – June 03, 2015}} The album was also commercially successful elsewhere, reaching number-one in France,{{cite web|url=http://www.infodisc.fr/B-CD_1992.php |title=Les Albums (CD) de 1992 par InfoDisc |language=French |publisher=InfoDisc |accessdate=31 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150711125153/http://www.infodisc.fr/B-CD_1992.php |archivedate=11 July 2015 |df= }} and reaching the top ten in New Zealand,{{cite web |url=http://charts.org.nz/showitem.asp?interpret=Sade&titel=Love+Deluxe&cat=a |title=Sade – Love Deluxe |publisher=charts.org.nz. Hung Medien |accessdate=31 March 2014}} Sweden,{{cite web |url=http://swedishcharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Sade&titel=Love+Deluxe&cat=a |title=Sade – Love Deluxe |publisher=swedishcharts.com. Hung Medien |accessdate=31 March 2014}} Switzerland{{cite web |url=http://swisscharts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Sade&titel=Love+Deluxe&cat=a |title=Sade – Love Deluxe |publisher=swisscharts.com. Hung Medien |accessdate=30 May 2008}} and the UK.{{cite web |url=http://www.officialcharts.com/archive-chart/_/3/1992-11-07/ |title=1992 Top 40 Official Albums Chart UK Archive |publisher=[[Official Charts Company]] |date=7 November 1992 |accessdate=31 March 2014}} The album went on to be certified gold in the United Kingdom. In November 1994, the group released their first compilation album, ''[[The Best of Sade]]''. The album was another top ten hit in both the United Kingdom and the United States,{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r207144|pure_url=yes}} |title=The Best Of Sade: Charts |accessdate=31 March 2009|work=allmusic.com }} certified platinum and four times platinum, respectively.{{cite web |url=https://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=best%20of%20sade&artist=SAde&format=&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2009&sort=Artist&perPage=25 |title=RIAA – Gold & Platinum |accessdate=30 March 2009|work=[[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]}} The compilation album included material from Sade's previous albums, as well as a [[cover version]] of "[[Please Send Me Someone to Love]]" (1950), originally by [[Percy Mayfield]].{{cite AV media notes |title=The Best of Sade |type=CD liner notes |others=[[Sade (band)|Sade]] |publisher=[[Epic Records]] |year=1994 |id=477793 2}} ===2000–10: ''Lovers Rock'' and second hiatus=== Following an eight-year hiatus, the band released their fifth studio album, ''[[Lovers Rock (Sade album)|Lovers Rock]]'', on 13 November 2000 and received positive reviews from music critics.{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/lovers-rock/sade/critic-reviews |title=Lovers Rock – Sade |publisher=[[Metacritic]]. [[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=13 January 2013}} The album reached number 18 on the [[UK Albums Chart]], number three on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]], and has since been certified triple platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA),{{Certification Cite Ref|region=United States|artist=Sade|title=Lovers Rock|award=Platinum|number=3|type=album|date=18 July 2001|accessdate=2 April 2014}} having sold 3.9 million copies in the United States by February 2010.{{cite web |last=Caulfield |first=Keith |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959427/sade-to-take-no-1-on-billboard-200-next-week |title=Sade To Take No. 1 On Billboard 200 Next Week |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=10 February 2010 |accessdate=17 February 2010}} On 27 February 2002, the album earned Sade the [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Vocal Album]],{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1845783.stm |title=Grammys 2002: The Winners |publisher=[[BBC News Online]] |date=28 February 2002 |accessdate=2 April 2014}} and the lead single "[[By Your Side (Sade song)|By Your Side]]" was nominated for the [[44th Grammy Awards|2002 Grammy Award]] for [[Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance|Best Female Pop Vocal Performance]]. Although the single lost out to [[Nelly Furtado]]'s "[[I'm Like a Bird]]", it has been listed as the 48th greatest love song of all time by [[VH1]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cs.ubc.ca/~davet/music/list/Best13.html|title=VH1 – 100 Greatest Love Songs (Music Database: Dave Tompkins)|work=[[University of British Columbia]]|last=Tompkins|first=Dave|accessdate=13 July 2014}} To promote the album, Sade and the band embarked on their fifth concert tour entitled [[Lovers Rock Tour]]. The tour was announced via the band's website in April 2001.{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1442927/sade-sets-north-american-tour-dates.jhtml |title=Sade Sets North American Tour Dates|last=Reimer|first=Courtney |date=18 April 2001 |work=[[MTV News]] |publisher=[[MTV Networks]] |accessdate=15 September 2012|archiveurl=http://www.freezepage.com/1347773500UBKWBFLTNQ?url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1442927/sade-sets-north-american-tour-dates.jhtml |archivedate=16 September 2012}} The announcement stated the tour would begin in the summer of 2001 with 30 shows. Initial dates were rescheduled due to extended rehearsal time. The shows sold well, with many stops adding additional shows. In August 2001, the tour was extended by eight weeks due to ticket demand.{{cite web |url=http://www.livedaily.citysearch.com/news/3460.html |title=Sade Adds More Dates to U.S. Tour |last=Zahlaway|first=Jon |date=7 August 2001 |work=LiveDaily |publisher=Ticketmaster Entertainment, Inc. |accessdate=15 September 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20011127043131/http://www.livedaily.citysearch.com/news/3460.html |archivedate=27 November 2001}} Deemed by many critics as a comeback tour, it marked the band's first performances since 1994 and took place in 2001. Although many believed the trek would expand to other countries, this did not occur. With over 40 shows, it became the 13th biggest tour in North America, earning over 26 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/467839/sade-the-billboard-cover-story |title=Sade: The Billboard Cover Story |last=Peters|first=Mitchell |date=19 August 2011 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |accessdate=15 September 2012}} Following the tour, the band released their first [[live album]], ''[[Lovers Live]]'' on 5 February 2002 by [[Epic Records]]. ''Lovers Live'' reached number ten on the US [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and number 51 on the [[UK Albums Chart]], the band's first album to miss the top twenty in the UK. The album was certified gold by the RIAA on 7 March 2002, having reached US sales of 562,000 copies,{{cite web |last=Caulfield |first=Keith |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/59627/ask-billboard |title=Ask Billboard – Class Acts |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |date=22 February 2006 |accessdate=9 February 2009}} while the DVD was certified platinum on 30 January 2003 for shipping 100,000 copies. Following the release of ''Lovers Rock'', Sade took a ten-year hiatus, during which she raised her son and moved to the Caribbean. During this time, she made a rare public appearance for an award ceremony that took place in 2002 to accept an [[Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) at [[Buckingham Palace]] for services to music.{{cite news|last1=Masson|first1=Gordon|title=Queen Elizabeth Honors Bee Gees, Sade, Betancourt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9Q8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA4&lpg=PA4&dq=%22British+Phonographic%22+sade&source=bl&ots=q-7tt_jQ2Z&sig=w1OS2PSHEXf5iWdMc7xToNTIvw0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEMQ6AEwCDgKahUKEwjuze_Y6-fHAhUMmYAKHVPHDSw#v=onepage&q=%22British%20Phonographic%22%20sade&f=false|work=Billboard|date=12 January 2002|page=4}} In 2002, she appeared on the [[Red Hot Organization]] album, ''[[Red Hot + Riot]]'', a compilation CD in tribute to the music of fellow Nigerian musician, [[Fela Kuti]]. She recorded a remix of her hit single "By Your Side" for the album and was billed as a co-producer. ===2010–present: '' Soldier of Love'', third hiatus and return=== [[File:Sade Adu 2.jpg|right|upright|thumb|Sade in 2011]] The band's sixth studio album, ''[[Soldier of Love (album)|Soldier of Love]]'', was released worldwide on 8 February 2010 and was the most recent album in ten years to contain new material. Upon release, the album received positive reviews and became a success.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/soldier-of-love/sade/critic-reviews|title=Critic Reviews for Soldier Of Love|publisher=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=20 February 2010}} The album debuted atop the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] in the United States with first-week sales of 502,000 copies. ''Soldier of Love'' became the band's first album to debut at number-one and the band's second album to peak at number-one on the chart. The album also had the best sales week by a group since Australian band [[AC/DC]] released their album ''[[Black Ice (album)|Black Ice]]'' and entered the ''Billboard'' 200 at number-one in November 2008.{{cite web |last=Caulfield |first=Keith |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/959357/sades-soldier-sizzles-at-no-1-on-billboard-200 |title=Sade's 'Soldier' Sizzles At No. 1 On Billboard 200 |work=Billboard |publisher=Prometheus Global Media |date=17 February 2010 |accessdate=17 February 2010}} Consequently, the band became the act with the longest hiatus between number-one albums, as the band's ''Promise'' (1985) and ''Soldier of Love'' were separated by 24 years, 10 months and 2 weeks.{{cite news|last1=Ramirez|first1=Rauly|title=Toni Braxton & Babyface’s Triumphant No. 1 Return to Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5908250/toni-braxton-babyfaces-triumphant-no-1-return-to-top-rbhip-hop-albums|accessdate=12 September 2015|work=Billboard|date=13 February 2014}} The first single and title track, "[[Soldier of Love (Sade song)|Soldier of Love]]", premiered on US radio on 8 December 2009{{cite web |url=http://www.sade.com/gb/news/2009-12-07/first_single_from_soldier_of_love/ |title=First Single From Soldier Of Love |publisher=sade.com |date=7 December 2009 |accessdate=12 April 2014 |deadurl=yes Of Love" Makes Radio History |publisher=NCBuy |date=23 December 2009 |accessdate=12 April 2014 }} and was released digitally on 11 January 2010.{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.fr/dp/B0031VZ2KS |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140412193958/http://www.amazon.fr/dp/B0031VZ2KS |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 April 2014 |title=Soldier Of Love (Single): Sade: Téléchargements MP3 |language=French April and 24 August 2010, respectively.{{cite web |url=http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/publishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=04/13/2010&Format=12 |title=Urban AC – Week Of: April 13, 2010 |work=[[Radio & Records]] |accessdate=12 April 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120615071509/http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/publishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=04%2F13%2F2010&Format=12 |archivedate=15 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }}{{cite web |url=http://gfa.radioandrecords.com/publishGFA/GFANextPage.asp?sDate=08/24/2010&Format=12 |title=Urban AC – Week Of: August 24, 2010 |work=Radio & |archivedate=7 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }} At the [[53rd Annual Grammy Awards]] in 2011, the title track won [[Grammy Award for Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals|Best R&B Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]], while the song, "Babyfather", was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Pop Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals|Best Pop Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocals]].{{cite web |url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees?year=2010&genre=All |title=Nominees And Winners |publisher=[[Grammy Award]]s. [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711123224/http://www.grammy.com/nominees?year=2010&genre=All |archivedate=11 July 2011 |accessdate=4 December 2014}} In April 2011, the band began their [[Sade Live]] tour (also known as the "Once in a Lifetime Tour" or the "Soldier of Love Tour").{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-juice/473195/john-legend-to-join-sade-on-tour |title=John Legend To Join Sade On Tour |last=Concepcion |first=Mariel |date=7 February 2011 |work=Billboard |accessdate=31 May 2011}} The band toured Europe, the Americas, Australia and Asia to promote the band's sixth studio album and their second [[compilation album]], ''[[The Ultimate Collection (Sade album)|The Ultimate Collection]]'' (2011). This trek marked the band's first tour in nearly a decade and{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/956003/sade-announces-first-tour-in-ten-years|title=Sade Announces First Tour In Ten Years |last=Concepcion |first=Mariel |date=30 September 2011 |work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]] |accessdate=31 May 2011}} ranked 27th in ''[[Pollstar|Pollstar's]]'' "Top 50 Worldwide Tour (Mid-Year)", earning over 20 million dollars.{{cite web |url=http://www.pollstarpro.com/files/Charts2011/071811Top50WorldwideTours.pdf |title=Top 50 Worldwide Tours (01/01/2011 – 06/30/2011) |date=8 July 2011 |work=Pollstar |publisher=Pollstar, Inc. |accessdate=15 July 2011}} At the conclusion of 2011, the tour placed tenth on ''Billboard's'' annual "Top 25 Tours", earning over $50 million with 59 shows.{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/42159/top-25-tours-of-2011 |title=Top 25 Tours of 2011|date=8 December 2011 |work=Billboard |accessdate=27 December 2011}} The tour was chronicled with [[Bring Me Home - Live 2011]], released in May, 2012. In March 2018, she (and the reunited [[Sade (band)|band that also bears her name]]) released the acoustic ballad "[[Flower of the Universe]]" for the soundtrack to the [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]] film ''[[A Wrinkle in Time (2018 film)|A Wrinkle In Time]]''. About asking Sade to contribute to the album, director [[Ava DuVernay]] wrote "I never thought she'd say yes, but asked anyway."{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/hear-sades-first-new-song-in-seven-years-w517506|title=Hear Sade's First New Song in Seven Years|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2018-03-06}} Later that year, Sade released "The Big Unknown" for the soundtrack to the [[20th Century Fox]] film ''[[Widows (2018 film)|Widows]]''. That film's director, [[Steve McQueen (director)|Steve McQueen]] stated that Sade agreed to write the song for the film, because "the original series of ''Widows'' had deeply resonated with her."[https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/sade-new-song-the-big-unknown-754481/ Hear Sade’s New ‘Widows’ Song ‘The Big Unknown’] The successor to ''[[Soldier of Love (album)|Soldier of Love]]'' is in the works.https://ratedrnb.com/2018/07/exclusive-sades-longtime-collaborator-says-shes-working-on-new-album/ ==Legacy and impact== ''[[The New Yorker]]'' described Sade's voice as a "grainy [[contralto]] full of air that betrays a slight ache but no agony, and values even imperfect dignity over a show of pain", a "deeply English" quality that makes categorizing the artist's voice difficult.{{cite news|last=Frere-Jones|first=Sasha|title=The Long War|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2010/03/22/the-long-war|accessdate=30 August 2015|work=The New Yorker|date=22 March 2010}} Her voice was described by the [[BBC]] as "husky and restrained" and compared to singer [[Billie Holiday]]. BBC called her songwriting "sufficiently soulful and jazzy yet poppy, funky yet easy listening, to appeal to fans of all those genres."{{cite web|last=Lester|first=Paul|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/4qvh|date=2010|title=BBC – Music – Review of Sade – Diamond Life|work=[[BBC]]}} Sade has been called a "pop star". With the musicians in her band, Sade, ''The New Yorker'' wrote, "created one of the most profitable catalogues in pop"; the band's "easy" sound backing songs "exploring the heavier lifting inside love: commitment, consistency, friendship." Her success has been attributed to a combination of her unique beauty, seemingly indefinable origins, and mysterious persona. Sade's work has influenced and been recognized by many singers and hip hop artists. Rapper [[Rakim]] of [[Eric B. & Rakim]] stated he grew up listening to Sade's music and was influenced by her voice and style. Rakim has also referenced Sade's song "Smooth Operator" in his rap song "[[Paid in Full (Eric B. & Rakim song)|Paid in Full]]" (1987). [[Talib Kweli]] stated he learned about precision from Sade due to her performance of ''Love Deluxe'' in its entirety at [[Madison Square Garden]]. Rapper [[Missy Elliott]] cited Sade's performance of "Smooth Operator" as one of her favourites. Hip hop group [[Souls of Mischief]] stated they grew up listening to Sade's music.{{cite web|url=http://www.vulture.com/2010/02/sade_memories_from_missy_ellio.html|title=Why Rappers Love Sade – Vulture|last=Barshad|first=Amos|work=Vulture}} Hip hop group [[Tanya Morgan]] also described Sade as one of their favorite artists. Other rappers to recognize Sade include the former rap-duo of [[Clipse]] – [[No Malice|Malice]] and [[Pusha T|Pusha]]. In reaction to the newly released album ''Soldier of Love'', rapper [[Kanye West]] wrote, "This is why i still have a blog. To be a part of moments like this ... new Sade ... How much better this ... than everything else?". Rapper [[Rick Ross]] stated in an interview that "People may know my infatuation with Sade. There's never been a bad Sade track. I love all different sides."{{cite news|last1=Anderson|first1=Kyle|title=Rick Ross on Chanting 2 Live Crew on the Playground – And the First Time He Fell in Love With a Stripper|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2014/12/15/rick-ross-hood-billionaire-strippers|accessdate=4 September 2015|work=Entertainment Weekly|date=19 December 2014}} American singer [[Beyoncé]] called Spears' comeback|work=[[Daily Mail]]|publisher=[[Associated Newspapers Ltd]]|date=25 July 2009|accessdate=10 June 2013|location=London}} ==Personal life== Sade [[Squatting|squatted]] in [[Wood Green]], North London, in the 1980s, with her then-boyfriend writer [[Robert Elms]].{{cite news|last=Mahoney|first=Elisabeth|title=Radio review: From Frestonia to Belgravia – The History of Squatting|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2011/nov/22/from-frestonia-to-belgravia-review?newsfeed=true|accessdate=22 November 2011|newspaper=The Guardian|date=22 November 2011|location=London}} In 1989, she married film director Carlos Pliego. Their marriage ended in 1995. Sade moved briefly to the [[Caribbean]] to live with [[Jamaica]]n music producer Bob Morgan in the late-1990s, but they later separated. During her relationship with Morgan, Sade gave birth to Mickailia, now known as Izaak, on 21 July 1996. Sade has been in a relationship with a former Royal Marine since 2007, and from this relationship she has a stepson. Morgan has nothing to do with their child. In 2016 on [[National Coming Out Day]], Izaak came out as [[transgender]] and is no longer known as Mickailia.{{cite web|url=http://www.bet.com/lifestyle/2016/10/06/sade-s-child-comes-out-as-a-transgender-man.html |title=Sade's Child Comes Out as a Transgender Man | Health | Lifestyle |publisher=BET |date=2016-10-05 |accessdate=2016-10-09}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bet.com/style/2017/08/16/sade-adu-transgender-son.html |title=Sade's Transgender Son Announces Breast Removal Surgery On Instagram |publisher=BET |date=8 August 2017 |accessdate=1 February 2018}} In 2005, Sade moved to [[Gloucestershire]]. In the countryside where she bought a run-down cottage to renovate. Prior to the release of ''[[Soldier of Love (album)|Soldier of Love]]'' in 2010, the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' described her as "famously reclusive".{{cite news|last= Littlejohn|first=Georgina|title= Sade Displays Her Youthful Looks as She Dresses Down After Her Glamorous Magazine Cover Hits the Shelves|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1257610/Sade-displays-youthful-looks-dresses-glamorous-magazine-cover-hits-shelves.html |work= [[Daily Mail]]|date= 12 March 2010|accessdate= 13 March 2010|location=London}} Sade rarely grants interviews. ==Honours, awards and nominations== {{Main|List of awards and nominations received by Sade}} Sade was appointed [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in 2002 for services to music, and stated her award was "a great gesture to me and all black women in England".{{cite news|title=Actress and Singer Collect OBEs|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/1934634.stm|accessdate=14 June 2012|work=BBC News|date=17 April 2002}} She was promoted to [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire|Commander of the same Order]] (CBE) in the [[2017 Birthday Honours]], also for services to music.{{London Gazette|issue=61962|supp=y|page=B8|date=17 June 2017}} ==Discography== {{Main|Sade discography}} {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} ;Studio albums *1984: ''[[Diamond Life]]'' *1985: ''[[Promise (Sade album)|Promise]]'' *1988: ''[[Stronger Than Pride]]'' *1992: ''[[Love Deluxe]]'' *2000: ''[[Lovers Rock (Sade album)|Lovers Rock]]'' *2010: ''[[Soldier of Love (album)|Soldier of Love]]'' {{col-end}} ==Tours== * 1984: Diamond Life Tour * 1986: [[Promise Tour]] * 1988: Stronger Than Pride Tour * 1993: [[Love Deluxe World Tour]] * 2001: [[Lovers Rock Tour]] * 2011: [[Sade Live]] ==See also== * [[Music history of the United States in the 1980s]] ==References== {{Reflist|25em}} ==Further reading== {{Refbegin|25em}} ;Books *{{cite book|last1=Bego|first1=Mark|title=Sade!|date=1986|publisher=Paperjacks|location=Toronto; {{Infobox person | name = Sarumathi Jayaraman | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = April 3, 1975 | birth_place = [[Whittier, California]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = American | education = [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (B.A.)
[[Yale Law School]] (J.D.) | home_town = | residence = | spouse = Zachary Norris | occupation = | children = 2 | parents = | family = }} '''Sarumathi "Saru" Jayaraman''' (born April 3, 1975) is an [[United States|American]] attorney, author, and activist from [[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]]. She is an advocate for restaurant workers in the (San Francisco) Bay Area and co-founder of the non-profit public service organization [[Restaurant Opportunities Centers United]]. == Early life == Born in 1975, Jayaraman was raised in a primarily Chicano neighborhood in [[Whittier, California]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.jamesbeard.org/content/2015-leadership-award-honoree-saru-jayaraman|title=James Beard Foundation|website=James Beard Foundation|access-date=2016-11-30}} Her parents emigrated from India to the United States when her father was seeking work as a software engineer. They settled in the Los Angeles area, but Jayaraman's father lost his job when she was a teenager. She was made aware of her class and race at a young age. Her family frequently endured racial slurs and insults. One incident from her childhood occurred when many mechanics refused to service her family's car when it broke down while they were road tripping across Utah.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Activist-at-vanguard-of-restaurant-workers-rights-5135081.php|title=Activist at vanguard of restaurant workers' rights|newspaper=SFGate|access-date=2016-11-30}} == Higher education == Jayaraman was accepted to [[Harvard University|Harvard]] at the age of sixteen, but her parents wanted her to stay close to home.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/21/business/an-outspoken-force-to-give-food-workers-a-seat-at-the-table.html|title=An Outspoken Force to Give Food Workers a Seat at the Table|last=Gelles|first=David|date=2016-02-20|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-30}} Sixteen-year-old Jayaraman attended [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] instead, where she earned her B.A. in International Development Studies and Political Science and graduated summa cum laude in 1995. She continued her education at [[Yale Law School]] and [[John F. Kennedy School of Government|Harvard Kennedy School of Government]]. In 2000, Jayaraman was admitted to the State Bars in California and New York.{{Cite web|url=http://laborcenter.berkeley.edu/cv/Saru_Jayaraman_CV.pdf|title=Saru Jayaraman|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} During her time at Yale, Jayaraman studied under [[John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Foundation|MacArthur Foundation]] Fellowship winner, [[Jennifer Gordon]]. Jayaraman was hired at Gordon's organization, the Workplace Project, where she dealt with training and organizing mistreated Latino immigrant workers to become their own advocates in instances of labor abuse. == ROC United == After [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]], thousands of workers from the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] were left jobless.Sen, Rinku with Mamdouh, Fekkak. The Accidental American: Immigration and Citizenship in the Age of Globalization. San Francisco, CA: Berrett-Koehler Publishers, 2008. The restaurant at the top of the World Trade was named [[Windows on the World]]. Jayaraman worked in partnership with Fekkak Mamdouh, the former chief server of Windows, to represent the displaced workers. The organization Jayaraman and Mamdouh founded together was named the Restaurant Opportunities Center of New York. Although it was originally established to help those affected by 9/11, the ROC evolved and became an organizing center for all immigrant restaurant workers in New York. Jayaraman headed the expansion effort and became the co-founder and director of Restaurant Opportunities Center United in 2007. ROC United, still headed by Jayaraman and Mamdouh, currently has over 18,000 members across 15 states. The organization deals with workplace justice campaigns, establishing living wages, and protecting workers rights. Jayaraman has been a key player in major advancements for low wage workers across the country.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/08/the-womens-labor-movement/497294/|title=A Labor Movement That's More About Women|last=Timm|first=Jonathan|newspaper=The Atlantic|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-01}} ROC United has won back more than $10 million for its members, and is continuing to fight through the [http://onefairwage.com ONE FAIR WAGE Campaign].{{Cite news|url=http://rocunited.org/our-work/|title=Our Work - rocunited|newspaper=rocunited|language=en-US|access-date=2016-12-01}} There are two federal minimum wages in the United States: $7.25 for untipped workers, and $2.13 for tipped workers. Jayaraman spearheads the fair wage campaign which seeks to eliminate this two tier system, and has already done so in [[California]], [[Oregon]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], [[Nevada]], [[Montana]], [[Minnesota]] and [[Alaska]]. ROC United was also instrumental in the passing of Washington's Accrued Sick and Safe Leave Act, which assures that all workers can begin accumulating sick leave after one day on the job.{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/interactive/2014/03/living/cnn10-visionary-women/|title=The CNN 10: Visionary Women|access-date=2016-12-01}} == Professional life and other activism == In 1992, Saru Jayaraman started a non-profit called Women and Youth Supporting Each Other (W.Y.S.E) which "empowers young women by providing the resources and support necessary to make positive life choices and create community change."{{Cite web|url=http://www.wyse.org|title=Women & Youth Supporting Each Other|website=Women & Youth Supporting Each Other|access-date=2016-12-01}} She was recognized by [[Bill Clinton|President Bill Clinton]] during his commencement speech and was praised as "America at its best." Jayaraman worked as a professor at various colleges in the New York area, teaching classes on a variety of topics, including political science, sociology, immigrants rights, and law. She also conducted research on food workers, sustainability, and urban poverty. Jayaraman has been serving as the leader of the Food Labor Research Center at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] since 2012. It is the first academic institution to study the relationship between food and labor. == Personal life == Jayaraman is married to [[Zachary Norris]], and has two daughters named Akeela Lalitha and Lina Abiani Norris-Raman.{{Cite book|title=Behind the Kitchen Door|last=Jayaraman|first=Saru|publisher=Ithaca, US: ILR Press|year=2013|isbn=|location=ProQuest ebrary|pages=|quote=|via=}} Jayaraman and Norris met at a Rebelling Lawyers Conference. Norris is now the executive director of the [[Ella Baker Center for Human Rights]] in San Francisco. == Works == Saru Jayaraman has written two books. ''The New Urban Immigrant Workforce'', released in 2005, is about modern methods of labor organizing. It draws on first hand accounts and ethnographies from workers in New York.Jayaraman, Saru, and Immanuel Ness (eds.). 2005. The New Urban Immigrant Workforce. ME Sharpe. New York, NY. ''Behind the Kitchen Door: The People Who Make and Serve Your Food'' was written in 2013. The book is about sexism, racism, and worker abuse in restaurants.Jayaraman, Saru. 2013. Behind the Kitchen Door: The People Who Make and Serve Your Food. Cornell University Press. Ithaca, NY. After the best-selling book gained national attention, Jayaraman did television interviews on [[PBS]], [[CNN]], [[MSNBC]], and [[HBO]]. In addition to her two books, Jayaraman has published numerous journal articles and technical reports. == Awards and honors == Jayaraman was named a Champion of Change by the [[Barack Obama|Obama]] administration in 2014, listed in CNN's "Top10 Visionary Women," and was awarded a [[James Beard Foundation]] Leadership Award in 2015. She was named one of Crain's New York Business "40 Under 40," 1010 Wins' "Newsmaker of the Year," and New York Magazine's "Influentials" of New York City."{{Cite web|url=http://laborcenter.berkeley.edu/author/saru-jayaraman/|title=Saru Jayaraman {{!}} Center for Labor Research and Education|website=laborcenter.berkeley.edu|access-date=2016-12-01}} In 2018 she was chosen by the [[National Women's History Project]] as one of its honorees for [[Women's History Month]] in the United States.{{cite web|url=https://www.kiro7.com/news/trending-now/national-womens-history-month-what-is-it-when-did-it-begin-who-is-being-honored-this-year-1/706593423|title=National Women's History Month: What is it, when did it begin, who is being honored this year?|first=|last=|date=25 February 2018|publisher=kiro7.com}} Other accolades: * [https://www.prime-movers.net/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/media-kit-2014.pdf Prime Movers Award.
