people|Tamils]]|[[Sri Lankan Tamil people|Sri Lankan Tamils]]|[[Dravidian peoples|Dravidians]]}} |footnotes = }} '''Sri Lankan Chetties''' ({{Lang-si|ශී ලංකා චෙට්ටි|translit=Śī laṁkā Ceṭṭi}}, {{Lang-ta|இலங்கை செட்டி|translit=Ilaṅkai Ceṭṭi}}) also known as '''Colombo Chetties''', is an ethnicity in the island of [[Sri Lanka]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.statistics.gov.lk/PopHouSat/CPH2011/index.php?fileName=pop42&gp=Activities&tpl=3|title=Census of Population and Housing 2011|website=www.statistics.gov.lk|access-date=2018-01-24}} Formerly considered a [[Sri Lankan Tamils|Sri Lankan Tamil]] caste, were classified as a separate ethnic group in the 2001 census.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=4N5UAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA27&dq=Sri+Lanka+Chetty+2001+census&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjmkbr75vDYAhXGjCwKHbfjBGgQ6AEINjAC#v=onepage&q=Sri%20Lanka%20Chetty%202001%20census&f=false|title=The Encyclopedia of the Sri Lankan Diaspora|last=Reeves|first=Peter|date=2014-03-07|publisher=Editions Didier Millet|year=|isbn=9789814260831|location=Institute of South Asian Studies, [[National University of Singapore]]|pages=27|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=Kj_aWm4DeFEC&pg=PA70&dq=sri+lanka+chetties+sinhalese+assimilate&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjY4ajM-vDYAhUEWCwKHUOHCMMQ6AEINzAC#v=onepage&q=chetties&f=false|title=The Sri Lanka Reader: History, Culture, Politics|last=Holt|first=John|date=2011-04-13|publisher=Duke University Press|year=|isbn=0822349825|location=|pages=70|language=en}} They were a class of [[Tamil language|Tamil speaking]] traders, who migrated from the [[South India]] under [[Portuguese Ceylon|Portuguese rule]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=1sCHCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA174&dq=Sri+Lankan+Chetties&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiO7ZKK4fDYAhVHjiwKHYa8AWoQ6AEIXjAI#v=onepage&q=Sri%20Lankan%20Chetties&f=false|title=Sri Lanka in the Modern Age: A History|last=Wickramasinghe|first=Nira|date=2015|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780190225797|location=174|pages=|language=en}} == Etymology == The word ''Chetty'' is a very general term denoting all merchant and trading groups of [[South India]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=Nwu3AAAAIAAJ&q=chetty+etymology&dq=chetty+etymology&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi72JrC6vDYAhXF3SwKHTRSBcIQ6AEIODAC|title=Population Review|last=|first=|date=1975|publisher=Indian Institute for Population Studies|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=26|language=en}} The word is thought to have been derived from the [[Tamil language|Tamil]] word ''Etti'', a [[honorific]] title bestowed on the leading merchants in the [[Chola dynasty|Chola kingdom]] and [[Pandya Kingdom]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=P3LiAAAAMAAJ&q=chetty+etymology&dq=chetty+etymology&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi72JrC6vDYAhXF3SwKHTRSBcIQ6AEIPjAD|title=People of India: Tamil Nadu, Volume 2|last=|first=|date=1997|publisher=Anthropological Survey of India|year=|isbn=9788185938882|location=|pages=1062|language=en}} ==History== {{See also|Chettiar}} [[File:Chetty in Ceylon (c. 1870).jpg|left|thumb|A Sri Lankan Chetty of 18th century|293x293px]]Most of them trace their origin from [[Madurai]], [[Tirunelveli]] and the [[Coromandel Coast]] of [[Southern India]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=50igCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA64&dq=Sri+Lanka+Chetty&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjhhrnQ7fDYAhUFDiwKHcTyDN84ChDoAQhCMAQ#v=onepage&q=Sri%20Lanka%20Chetty&f=false|title=Historical Dictionary of Sri Lanka|last=Peebles|first=Patrick|date=2015-10-22|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=|isbn=9781442255852|location=|pages=64|language=en}} They settled mostly in western and nort hern [[Sri Lanka]], especially in the ports of [[Colombo]], [[Jaffna]] and [[Galle]] from the 16th century to mid 17th century, during the rule of the Portuguese and Dutch.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?hl=no&id=H7xWAAAAMAAJ&dq=jaffna+chetties&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=chetties|title=An outline of the cultural history and principles of Hinduism|last=Sivaratnam|first=C.|date=1964|publisher=Stangard Printers|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=276|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=dByI_qil26YC&pg=PA175&dq=jaffna+chetties&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjR4ZyE8PDYAhWBoiwKHcjOBGw4ChDoAQhpMAk#v=onepage&q=jaffna%20chetties&f=false|title=A History of Sri Lanka|last=Silva|first=K. M. De|date=1981|publisher=University of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520043206|location=|pages=175|language=en}} Some of the Chetties in Northern Sri Lanka were absorbed in other communities, mainly in the [[Sri Lankan Vellalar]] community, considered a subcaste known as ''Chetty Vellalar'' .{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=1sCHCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA274&dq=jaffna+chetties&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi3qbnA8fDYAhWMjywKHQ2AAJI4FBDoAQg2MAI#v=onepage&q=jaffna%20chetties&f=false|title=Sri Lanka in the Modern Age: A History|last=Wickramasinghe|first=Nira|date=2015|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=|isbn=9780190225797|location=|pages=274|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?hl=no&id=7smFAAAAIAAJ&dq=karaiyar+chetty&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=chetty|title=Sri Lanka, A country study|last=F. Nyrop,|first=Richard|publisher=Foreign Area Studies|year=1986|isbn=|location=[[American University]], Washington, D.C.|pages=108}} The Chetties of Western Sri Lanka converted to [[Roman Catholic church|Roman Catholicism]] under [[Portuguese Ceylon|Portuguese rule]]. Other converted to [[Anglicanism]] or [[Protestantism]] under [[Dutch Ceylon|Dutch rule]] and [[British Ceylon|British rule]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=DntuAAAAMAAJ&q=sri+lanka+chetties+roman+catholic&dq=sri+lanka+chetties+roman+catholic&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXwsHr-PDYAhVKiaYKHZ6bCWMQ6AEIKDAA|title=Cultural minorities of Sri Lanka: their growth, achievements, and relevance today|last=Vijayalakshmi|first=E.|last2=Studies|first2=International Centre for Ethnic|date=2005-01-01|publisher=International Centre for Ethnic Studies|year=|isbn=9789555800969|location=|pages=8|language=en}} Intermarriage and alliances between [[Sinhalese people|Sinhalese]] and Chetties were not uncommon thus many also got [[Sinhalisation|Sinhalised]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=DntuAAAAMAAJ&q=sri+lanka+chetty+dutch&dq=sri+lanka+chetty+dutch&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjq4vLA9fDYAhVJ_SwKHZ2TAaM4FBDoAQhOMAU|title=Cultural minorities of Sri Lanka: their growth, achievements, and relevance today|last=Vijayalakshmi|first=E.|last2=Studies|first2=International Centre for Ethnic|date=2005-01-01|publisher=International Centre for Ethnic Studies|year=|isbn=9789555800969|location=|pages=10|language=en}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=50igCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA78&dq=sri+lanka+chetties+assimilate&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj3iNqI-_DYAhUBiiwKHQ3uCnsQ6AEIMDAB#v=onepage&q=sri%20lanka%20chetties%20assimilate&f=false|title=Historical Dictionary of Sri Lanka|last=Peebles|first=Patrick|date=2015-10-22|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|year=|isbn=9781442255852|location=|pages=78|language=en}}{{Historical populations |type = |footnote = Source:[[Department of Census & Statistics, Sri Lanka|Department of Census
& Statistics]]{{cite web|title=Population by ethnic group, census years|url=http://www.statistics.gov.lk/abstract2010/chapters/Chap2/AB2-10.pdf|publisher=Department of Census & Statistics, Sri Lanka|accessdate=23 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111113175023/http://www.statistics.gov.lk/abstract2010/chapters/Chap2/AB2-10.pdf|archivedate=13 November 2011|df=}}
Data is based on
[[Sri Lankan Government]] Census. |2001 | 10800 |2011 | 6075 }} Representatives of the ''Colombo Chetty Association'' stressed out their distinctiveness, appealing for forming a separate ethnic group. The Chetties were notably also from 1814 to 1817 listed as a separate ethnic group.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=Y-xQ8qk9mgYC&pg=PA165&dq=sri+lanka+chetty+separate&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwihgr7N_PDYAhVEjCwKHXVODVwQ6AEIKDAA#v=onepage&q=sri%20lanka%20chetty%20separate&f=false|title=Sri Lanka in the Modern Age: A History of Contested Indentities|last=Wickramasinghe|first=Nira|date=2006|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|year=|isbn=9780824830168|location=|pages=165|language=en}} The Chetties used dress distinctive from rest of the population in the colonial era.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.no/books?id=QqIzh1StFiwC&pg=PA82&dq=colombo+chetty&hl=no&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjU9dbT7vDYAhVJXCwKHfheAmUQ6AEITjAF#v=onepage&q=colombo%20chetty&f=false|title=Buying and Believing: Sri Lankan Advertising and Consumers in a Transnational World|last=Kemper|first=Steven|date=2001|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=|isbn=9780226430409|location=|pages=82|language=en}} As an elite and prosperous group they no longer strictly marry amongst themselves. In addition, migration to [[Australia]], [[England]], [[United States of America]] and [[Canada]] has tended to dilute their numbers.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} ==See also== *[[Simon Casie Chetty]] *[[Bharatakula]] *[[Nagarathar]] *[[Chitty|Malacca Chitty]] *[[Jeyaraj Fernandopulle]] ==References== ;Sources * Casiechitty S, The Castes, Customs, Manners and Literature of the Tamils. Colombo: Ceylon Printers, 1934. * Pulle Tissera Shirley - History of The Colombo Chetties - 2000 * Thurston E, Castes and Tribes of Southern India ;Notes {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.rootsweb.com/~lkawgw/gen7010.html Dutch Burgher/Sri Lankan Chetty Combined Genealogy list] *[http://www.lankalibrary.com/cul/hybride.htm Sri Lankan Hydridity] *[http://www.rootsweb.com/~lkawgw/gen7000.html Ondaatje Family history] {{Immigration to Sri Lanka}} {{NRI-PIO}} [[Category:Sri Lankan caste system|Chetties]] [[Category:Sri Lankan Chetties| ]] [[Category:Sri Lankan Tamil society|Chetties]] [[Category:Tamil diaspora in Asia|Chetties]] [[Category:Sri Lankan Tamil castes]]

{{Infobox person | name = ''Maharaja Adhiraj Rajaraam''
Dr. Tony Nader | image = Dr Tony Nader.jpg | image_size = 200px | alt = Tony Nader, Leader of the World-Wide Transcendental Meditation Organization, Global Country of World Peace, and Successor to Maharishi Mahesh Yogi. | caption = Tony Nader in 2012 | birth_name = Tony Nader | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Lebanon]] | residence = [[MERU]], [[Vlodrop]], the Netherlands | nationality = Lebanese | alma_mater = [[American University of Beirut]], [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] | occupation = Leader of the world-wide Transcendental Meditation organization, neurologist, scientist, author }} '''Tony Nader''' (Born: '''Tanios Abou Nader''' Canadian corporate record for Global Country of World Peace: [https://www.ic.gc.ca/app/scr/cc/CorporationsCanada/fdrlCrpDtls.html?corpId=4261143]; Arabic: طوني أبو ناضر) is a Lebanese neuro-scientist, researcher,Ulall, Surendra (May 4, 2012) ''India Post''. [http://issuu.com/indiapost/docs/indiapost_05-04-2012?mode=window&viewMode=singlePage "Iowa scholars give scientific exposition of Ramayana"]. Retrieved May 25, 2012 "Tony Nader, M.D., Ph.D., neuroscientist and researcher."Luhar, Monica (April 4, 2012) [http://indiawest.com/news/3848-new-paradigm-tour-veda-consciousness-the-ramayana-and-the-self.html New Paradigm Tour: ‘Veda, Consciousness, The Ramayana, and the Self’] ''India-West'', retrieved May 25, 2012. "Neuro scientist and researcher, Tony Nader" university president, author and leader of the [[Transcendental Meditation movement]]. He has a medical degree in internal medicine, received his Ph.D. from [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] and worked as a clinical and research fellow at a teaching hospital of [[Harvard Medical School]]. Nader worked with [[Deepak Chopra]] at the [[Maharishi Ayurveda]] Health Center in Massachusetts{{Cite journal | last1 = Nader | first1 = T. | last2 = Rothenberg | first2 = S. | last3 = Averbach | first3 = R. | last4 = Charles | first4 = B. | last5 = Fields | first5 = J. Z. | last6 = Schneider | first6 = R. H. | title = Improvements in chronic diseases with a comprehensive natural medicine approach: a review and case series. | journal = Behav Med | volume = 26 | issue = 1 | pages = 34–46 | year = 2000 |PMID = 10971882| url= http://heldref.metapress.com/link.asp?id=77438hjn4244328q | doi=10.1080/08964280009595751 | pmc=2408890}} and in 1994, published his first book, ''Human Physiology: Expression of Veda and the Vedic literature''. He is president of both Maharishi University of Management (Holland) and Maharishi Open University. In 2000, Nader received the title of First Sovereign Ruler of the conceptual country, [[Global Country of World Peace]] from [[Transcendental Meditation]] founder [[Maharishi Mahesh Yogi]],{{cite news|title='Peace palace' project launched by Maharishi's followers|first=Mark |last=Abley|work=The Gazette|location=Montreal, Que.|date=May 2, 2003|page=A.6}} and in 2008, was named the Maharishi's successor.{{cite news|title=Maharishi's ashes immersed in Sangam|work=The Hindustan Times|location= New Delhi|date=February 12, 2008|agency=Indo-Asian News Service}} Nader published his second book, ''Ramayan In Human Physiology'' in 2011. In 2015 Nader founded the ''International Journal of Mathematics and Consciousness'' and is serving as the editor-in-chief.Editorial board, ''International Journal of Mathematics and Consciousness'' [http://www.ijmac.com/editorial-board] ==Education== Nader attended the [[American University of Beirut]] where he studied internal medicine and psychiatry, and received his master's degree,Durst-Andersen, Per and Lange, Elsebeth F. (2010) Copenhagen Business School Press, ''Mentality and Thought: North, South, East and West'', p. 69 and a medical degree in internal medicine and psychiatry,Nader, Tony (1994) Maharishi Vedic University, ''Human Physiology: Expression of Veda and the Vedic Literature'', "Professor Nader received his MD degree from the American University of Beirut where he also studied internal medicine and psychiatry" p. 1Williams, Patrick Gresham, ''The Spiritual Recovery Manual: Vedic Knowledge and Yogic Techniques for Addicts, Codependents and Adult Children of Dysfunctional Families'', "Dr. Nader is an M.D. with a Ph.D. from MIT", p. 230 He earned his Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the field of Brain and Cognitive ScienceN. Begum, (June 1, 2012) ''News India Times'', [http://www.newsindia-times.com/newsindiatimes/20120424/5350620558282608045.htm Hundreds Attend Program to Promote Vedic Learning], retrieved June 2, 2012Smith, Frederick and Wujastyk, Dagmar (2008) State University of New York Press, Albany, ''Modern and Global Ayurveda: Pluralism and Paradigms'', "Tony Nader an M.D. who also received a Ph.D. in neuroscience from MIT" p. 14 and became a visiting physician at their Clinical Research Center. His post-doctoral work was as a clinical and research fellow at the [[Massachusetts General Hospital]], a teaching hospital of [[Harvard Medical School]].Chopra, Deepak (1987) Harper & Row, ''Creating Health: How to Wake Up the Body’s Intelligence'', "Tony Nader, M.D., neuroscientist, Harvard Medical School and MIT" p. 212{{cite news|title=Forget the F-16s, Israel needs more Yogic Flyers to beat Hizbullah. 30-strong TM group, sole guests at Nof Ginnosar Hotel, say they need another 235 colleagues to make the country safe|first=Amir|last=Mizroch|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=July 23, 2006|page=04|url=}} ==Career== Nader has conducted research in hormonal activity, neurochemistry, neuroendocrinology, on the medical role of the neurotransmitter and on the relationship between age, behavior, diet, seasonal influences and mood. Nader reports that his desire to have a complete understanding of the mind and body and its relationship to consciousness and the human physiology, led him to a "spiritual awakening" and the study of Vedic Science with the Maharishi. Nader said he learned about "the field of spiritual or non-physical, or non-material and how it expresses itself in the universe" from the Maharishi. As a professor and director, Nader has conducted [[Maharishi Vedic Approach to Health]] programs and lectured in "more than 50 countries". In 1986 Nader was criticized for overstating his post-graduate connections to MIT and implying that his research was sanctioned by his alma mater.Brink, Susan (October 2, 1991) [https://archive.is/20120722112514/pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/69030511.html?dids=69030511:69030511&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+02,+1991&author=SUSAN+BRINK&pub=Boston+Herald&desc=Journal+charges+doc+with+interest+conflict&pqatl=google] Journal charges doc with interest conflict. ''Boston Herald'', p. 9. "The journal also found that others connected with the business, including Dr. Tony Nader, overstated their ties to prestigious institutions, such as Harvard, MIT and Massachusetts General Hospital. Nader was asked in a 1986 letter by Dr. Richard Wurtman of MIT not to imply that Nader's 'low-grade kind of investigation' is sanctioned by MIT." In 1987, Nader worked at the Maharishi Ayurveda Health Center in [[Lancaster, Massachusetts|Lancaster]], Massachusetts.{{cite news|title=No Coffee, No Booze, No Smoking, No Steaks – But Lots Of Oil|first=Curtis|last=Wilkie|work=The Boston Globe|date=December 13, 1987|page=12}}"After morning treatment, have a final consultation with Chopra's associate, Dr. Nader." In his 1994 book ''Human Physiology: Expression of Veda and the Vedic Literature'', Nader postulated a one-to-one correlation of structure and function between 40 aspects of Vedic literature and 40 parts of human physiology.Raval, Indravan B. (2001) "Non-Traditional Interpretation of 'Anarthaka Hi Mantrah' ''Journal of the Oriental Institute'', Vol. 50, Nos. 1–4, Sept. – June 2001, pp. 17–22{{cite news|title='Vedas' influence on human anatomy proved|work=The Hindu |location=Chennai |date=January 30, 1997|page=1|first=Ian|last=Brown}} He also said he discovered similarities between the astrological influence of the planets and parts of the human brain. This body of work is reported to have been "derived from" the Maharishi's ideas, and Nader's own training in brain physiology. In May 1995, Nader was a keynote speaker at [[Maharishi University of Management]] and presented his "recent discovery of how Natural Law manages the physiology, and the application of this knowledge to prevent and eliminate problems."(1995) ''The Economist'', Vol. 335, Issues 1713–7916, "Keynote speaker Tony Nader, MD, Ph.D., will present his recent discovery of how Natural Law manages the physiology, and the application of this knowledge to prevent and eliminate problems in all areas of management." The book has been described as an attempt at documenting the scientific basis of the Maharishi's "interpretation of Advaita Vedanta and thus the Vedas … by relating neuroanatomy and neurophysiology to Vedic astrology and philosophy". According to a press release, Nader was recognized for his "scientific discovery" in 1998, when he was awarded his weight in gold by Maharishi Vedic University of Holland, "with the support of the Maharishi Global Development Fund". The gold was reportedly given to Nader as a scientific award to support his continued research.{{Cite book| publisher = MIT Press| isbn = 9780262050791| last = Easterling| first = Keller| title = Enduring innocence| date = November 1, 2005|page= 82|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sQN2Fpyxku8C&pg=PA82&dq=Enduring+innocence+%22tony+nader%22+gold&cd=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false}}{{cite press release|title=Natural Law Party: Opening a new highway for perfection in life|publisher=M2 Presswire|location=Coventry|date=February 6, 1998|url=http://www.natural-law-party.org.uk/pressreleases/UK-19980206-Tony-Nader-receives-his-weight-in-gold.htm|archivedate=September 16, 2010|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5snPYyU2X}} Nader performed the first research on [[Maharishi Vedic Vibration Technology]] (MVVT), which aims "to enliven the inner intelligence of the body and restore proper functioning" through the use of Vedic sounds. Nader's studies were conducted in Berlin, Paris, and Valkenburg, testing the effectiveness of one session of MVVT in people with disorders that included arthritis, asthma, and gastrointestinal disorders.{{Cite web|title=Science and Vedic Sound|publisher=Maharishi's Vedic Vibration Technology web site|url=http://www.mvvt.org/Science%20and%20Vedic%20Sound%20english.htm|archivedate=September 16, 2010|archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/5snPh16gH|first=Steele |last=Belok}}[[File:Global Country headquarters.JPG|thumb|Global Country of World Peace capital building in Maharishi Vedic City|alt=A photograph of a two-storey building. The roof is topped with a large cupola and three visible kalashes. Golden letters on the pediment say "CAPITAL OF THE GLOBAL COUNTRY OF WORLD PEACE". There is a circular driveway with a flagpole bearing the GCWP's sunburst flag. The building and drive are surrounded by a white picket fence, green lawn, and shrubbery.]] During a four-day Vedic ceremony in October 2000, Nader was honored by Maharishi as [[Maharaja]] (great king) Adhiraj Rajaraam and given responsibility for the Global Country of World Peace and, in 2008, became the Maharishi's successor.{{cite web|url=http://www.mou.org/mou/overview/raja_nader_ram/index.html |title=Coronation of Vishwa Prashasak Raja Raam|accessdate=January 18, 2010|publisher=Maharishi Open University |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20020705202507/http://www.mou.org/mou/overview/raja_nader_ram/index.html |archivedate = July 5, 2002}} During these transitions, Nader was reportedly given various titles including "Vishwa Prashasak Raja Raam", "Adhi Raam", and "Raja Nader Raam".Pradhan, Sharat (February 11, 2008) [http://www.rediff.com/news/2008/feb/11maha.htm Allahabad: Maharishi Mahesh Yogi cremated] Rediff India Abroad, retrieved April 2, 2012{{Cite book|last1=Reddy|first1=Kumuda|last2=Egenes|first2=Thomas|last3=Egenes|first3 = Linda | title = All Love Flows to the Self: Eternal Stories from the Upanishads | year =1999 | publisher = Samhita Productions | isbn = 978-1-929297-05-4 |page=xvi}}(February 12, 2008) [http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2008-02-11/india/27772046_1_maharishi-mahesh-yogi-tony-nader-maharajadhiraj-raja-ram Maharishi's ashes immersed in Sangam], ''Times of India'', New Delhi, "the disciples of Maharishi Mahesh Yogi on Sunday formally 'crowned' Tony Nader of Lebanon as his successor. [[Donald Glover]] in flashbacks ("[[Live from Studio 6H]]") | creator = [[Tina Fey]] }} '''Tracy Jordan''' is a [[fictional character]] in the American television series ''[[30 Rock]]'', played by the actor [[Tracy Morgan]]. The character is a [[movie star]] whose personality traits and life events are taken from Morgan's own life. In the episode "Grandmentor", Jordan refers to himself as "Tracy Morgan". In 2010, ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' ranked him the 55th Greatest Character of the Last 20 Years.{{cite web|title=The 100 Greatest Characters of the Last 20 Years: Here's our full list!|url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2010/06/01/100-greatest-characters-of-last-20-years-full-list/|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|publisher=[[Time Inc.]]|accessdate=July 7, 2012|author=Adam B. Vary|date=June 1, 2010}} For his portrayal of Jordan, [[Tracy Morgan]] has received one [[Primetime Emmy Award]] nomination, two [[Image Awards]] nominations, and seven [[Screen Actors Guild Award]] nominations, winning one.{{cite web|title=Tracy Morgan Awards|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0605079/awards?ref_=nm_awd|website=imdb.com|publisher=IMDb.com Inc|accessdate=28 August 2014}} ==Concept== Tracy Jordan is a rich, famous B-list movie star with a reputation for unpredictable behavior. At the time newly installed NBC executive [[Jack Donaghy]] forces writer [[Liz Lemon]] to hire Jordan as the new star of her [[sketch comedy]] program ''The Girlie Show'' in [[Pilot (30 Rock)|the pilot episode]] of the series, Jordan was in a career slump, having made no new movies for two years. Upon hiring Tracy, Jack renames the show ''TGS with Tracy Jordan,'' much to the chagrin of Liz. Throughout the series, Jordan enjoys renewed success through his starring ''TGS'' role and other performances and ventures. ==Character history== Jordan is a descendant of [[Thomas Jefferson]] and slave [[Sally Hemings]].{{Cite episode|title=Fireworks|episodelink=Fireworks (30 Rock)|series=30 Rock|serieslink=30 Rock|credits=Writers: [[Brett Baer]] and [[Dave Finkel]]|network=[[NBC]]|location=[[New York City]]|airdate=2007-04-05|season=1|number=18|minutes=}} Jordan was born in [[Yankee Stadium (1923)|Yankee Stadium]] but the exact date is unknown as he has no birth certificate. He was given the honorary birthday of February 24, shared with ''[[The Girlie Show (fictional show)|TGS]]'' Co-star [[Jenna Maroney]] in the March 5, 2009 episode "Goodbye, My Friend". Tracy grew up in a tough neighborhood in [[The Bronx]], though many of his claims about it sound fictitious. As a child, Jordan was a cast member on the [[Nickelodeon (TV Channel)|Nickelodeon]] show ''Ray Ray's Mystery Garage''. He also claims to have attended middle school in an [[Exxon]] station. He lived with his single mother in 1979, dropped out of [[Frank Lucas (drug lord)|Frank Lucas]] [[High school (North America)|High School]] over his inability to dissect a frog, and claims to have spent time [[Street performance|busking]] as a bucket drummer. He was discovered after doing [[stand-up]] at the [[Apollo Theater|Apollo]] in 1984.{{Cite episode|title=The Head and the Hair|episodelink=The Head and the Hair (30 Rock)|series=30 Rock|serieslink=30 Rock|credits=Writers: [[Tina Fey]] and [[John Riggi]]|network=[[NBC]]|location=[[New York City]]|airdate=2007-01-18|season=1|number=11|minutes=5:11}} Jordan did a [[Christmas]] [[album]] in 1998 and is a big fan of [[Pat Benatar]]. In addition to his acting career, he writes a column in ''[[Ebony Magazine]]'' called "Musings". He owns several houses but got into debt because he didn't make the payments on them. ==Character traits== Jordan is a self-centered prima donna. For instance, in "[[Operation Righteous Cowboy Lightning]]", Tracy says, "Perfection is my middle name. 'Unclaimed Perfection Baby Boy'." He aspires to own an island. Jordan is treated for a mental health disorder by [[Dr. Leo Spaceman]], a doctor of questionable integrity and qualification, who describes Tracy's problems as "erratic tendencies and delusions brought on by excessive notoriety and certainly not helped by my (Spaceman's) highly experimental treatments." He is unable to perform a scene the same way twice ("[[Future Husband]]"), making his employ as an actor difficult. Jordan is also a [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy theorist]] who believes, for instance, in shadow organizations and vampires. Despite all this, the character is supposed to be generally well-meaning and more intelligent than he appears. He periodically surprises his coworkers with his knowledge of proper grammar (for example, telling Toofer in "[[The Aftermath (30 Rock)|The Aftermath]]" that "Superman does ''good'', you're doing ''well''") and advanced vocabulary, though these vignettes are often played for comedy. He is able to remember details of American history and is able to answer trivia questions correctly. He also has a sensitivity to the mistreatment of [[African American]]s. Tracy has an interest in [[American Revolution]]ary history, which he studied after learning of his relation to Thomas Jefferson, attempting to produce and star in a Jefferson biopic. In "[[Corporate Crush]]", while struggling to secure funding for his film, he tells Liz "You're my [[Alexander Hamilton]]!" In "[[Winter Madness]]" he argues with several [[Freedom Trail]] historical reenactors in Boston for misrepresenting the racism of the Founding Fathers and the date of [[Crispus Attucks]]' death. Jordan often implies that his clownish behavior is mostly an act, which he maintains because his childish persona is responsible for his success as an entertainer. This seems to be supported by Jordan's occasional moments of maturity, such as when he behaves professionally for an entire week in "[[The Natural Order]]" to prove to Liz Lemon that he is capable of acting like an adult. However, he soon reverts to his old personality, admitting he is more comfortable being immature. ==Relationships== ===Family=== Tracy and his wife [[List of 30 Rock characters#Angie Jordan|Angie]] have been married since 1991. They like to [[sexual roleplaying|roleplay]], including [[rape fantasy|'playing rape']], when he wears a [[ski mask]]. Jordan often walks around his house naked to show his oldest male child "who got the biggest [[penis|ding-dong]]". With Angie, Tracy has two sons, named Tracy Jordan Jr. and George Foreman Jordan (played by Dante E. Clark), and a daughter, Virginia, who is born during season 5. Tracy also has a self-styled illegitimate son named Donald (played by Michael Benjamin Washington), an entrepreneur whom Tracy supports financially despite knowing that he is not actually his son; Donald is two years older than Tracy. Although he "parties with women to keep up his rap credentials," Tracy maintains loyalty to his wife, admitting to [[Jack Donaghy]] in "[[The Ones (30 Rock)|The Ones]]" that he has never cheated on her. Because his womanizing persona is integral to his success as an entertainer, Tracy's career takes a downturn in "[[Don Geiss, America and Hope|Don Geiss, America, and Hope]]" when his monogamy becomes known to the public, in a reverse parody of the [[Tiger Woods]] infidelity scandal of 2009. Tracy spent most of his childhood in [[foster care]]. He once lived with his birth mother, but lost touch with her: in "[[The Moms]]" he is not sure of her whereabouts or even her name. Tracy's biological father is unknown; Tracy presumes him dead since he has never come forward to ask Tracy for money. In "[[Nothing Left to Lose (30 Rock)|Nothing Left to Lose]]," Tracy shares memories of a father who abandoned him for a second family in Ohio (going on to have a daughter who is also named Tracy), but the effect of this upon the show's continuity is unclear. ===With Liz=== Tracy refers to Liz by either her last name or her full name, for example, "Too late, Liz Lemon!" Jordan treats Liz with contempt and mimics her. However, in later seasons he begins calling her "LL", following a trend of often calling characters by their initials. ===With his entourage and friends=== Jordan tends to loiter around the studio with his entourage, former high school classmate [[List of 30 Rock characters#Grizz|Grizz]] and professional entourage member [[List of 30 Rock characters#Dot Com|Dot Com]]. Jordan develops a close friendship with NBC page [[Kenneth Parcell]], who willingly runs errands for him and periodically serves as a member of his entourage. Kenneth often puts himself in harm's way to help Jordan. Jordan helps Kenneth with his shyness around women, and considers himself a mentor to Kenneth. He is more sympathetic to Kenneth than most of the other characters are. For example, when Tracy quit TGS after learning he no longer needed the money he earned from the show, it was Jack's threat to fire Kenneth that made Tracy change his mind, returning to the show in order to keep Kenneth employed ("[[The Bubble (30 Rock)|The Bubble]]"). Kenneth acted as an asexual, de facto, on-set wife to Jordan during his brief estrangement from Angie (Season 2). ===With Jenna=== Jordan and Jenna often disagree. For instance, whether it is more difficult to be a black man or a white woman in America ("[[Believe in the Stars]]"). However, they have some friendly moments at times and become closer, assuming they are both "special people". There is also an increasing occurrence of the two being involved in shenanigans together. ==Jordan's life== ===Career=== Jordan has a reputation for being uncontrollable and his habit of insulting powerful movie executives costs him roles. However, Jordan's engagements are many and varied. ===Politics=== Jordan is not overly interested in politics. Jack tried to recruit Jordan to join the Republican Party, but Jordan came to realize that African-Americans would never support the GOP. In 2007 Tracy's wife objects to him playing [[Barack Obama]] because, "...we support [Dennis] [[Dennis Kucinich|Kucinich]]." In the [[2008 US Presidential Election]], Jordan voted for [[Ralph Nader]]. ===Religion=== Jordan is not religious. He once considers becoming Catholic but is dissuaded by Jack due to, as expected, intolerance of guilt. In "[[The Ones (30 Rock)|The Ones]]," when Jordan arranges for Jack to come clubbing with him to see if Jack can remain faithful to his fiancée Elisa, Jordan compares the temptation to "Jesus in the wilderness," before clarifying that Jesus is the name of a person he knows and "the Wilderness" is a club they'd attended. Jordan once wrote a novelty song entitled "[[Werewolf]] [[Bar Mitzvah]]", which he recorded for [[Geffen Records]]. The lyrics include "Werewolf bar mitzvah, spooky, scary! Boys becoming men; men becoming wolves!" He learns some Hebrew phrases. In the first episode of season 4 (entitled Season Four) of the show, it is revealed that Tracy may as well actually be Jewish. When asked about his disconnection to his roots, he said, "Have I lost touch with my roots? I've gotta talk to Rabbi Shmuely (referring most likely to [[Shmuly Boteach]]) about this." ===Finances=== Despite his personality difficulties, Jordan succeeds financially. For example, he makes $300 million by creating and marketing a pornographic video game, and then invests the profits in a company that dismantles bank signs during the financial crisis. ==Trivia== In Tina Fey's original pilot script for ''30 Rock'', Jordan was called "Lawrence Jordan".[http://www.zen134237.zen.co.uk/30_Rock/30_Rock_1x01_-_Pilot.pdf] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111030222006/http://www.zen134237.zen.co.uk/30_Rock/30_Rock_1x01_-_Pilot.pdf |date=October 30, 2011 }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote|30 Rock}} {{30 Rock}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jordan, Tracy}} [[Category:30 Rock characters]] [[Category:Fictional actors]] [[Category:Fictional African-American people]] [[Category:Fictional comedians]] [[Category:Fictional criminals]] [[Category:Fictional characters from New York City]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2006]] [[Category:Fictional television personalities]] [[Category:Narcissism in fiction]]

'''Wilber Brotherton Huston''' (October 2, 1912 – May 25, 2006) was an [[United States|American]] scientist and [[NASA]] mission director. He was the Deputy Project Manager of the [[Nimbus program]] and served as mission director for seven satellite launches. At the age of sixteen he had won the first [[Thomas Edison|Edison]] Scholarship Contest.
==Biography== Huston was born in [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], the first child of the Reverend [[Simeon Arthur Huston|S. Arthur Huston]], [[curate]] at [[Cathedral Church of St. Paul, Detroit|St. Paul's Cathedral]], and the former Dorothea J. Brotherton. His parents named him for [[Wilber Brotherton]], his maternal grandfather, who was the manager of the Detroit operations of the [[Jerome B. Rice Seed Company]]. The ''Wilber'' spelling, instead of ''Wilbur'', derived from admiration for [[William Wilberforce]], the English [[Abolitionism in the United Kingdom|abolitionist]]. His maternal grandmother was [[Belle Brotherton]], a leader in the [[women's suffrage]] movement.
Between 1913 and 1925 Huston, as a minister's son, lived in [[Cheyenne, Wyoming]], [[Baltimore, Maryland]], and [[San Antonio, Texas]]. In 1925, when his father was [[consecration|consecrated]] as [[Bishop]] of the [[Episcopal Diocese of Olympia]], his family settled in [[Seattle, Washington]], and Huston enrolled at [[Lakeside School (Seattle, Washington)|Lakeside School]] from which he graduated in 1929.
Early in 1929 [[Thomas Edison]] called a [[news conference]] to announce a national [[competition|contest]] with the winner to receive an all-expenses-paid [[scholarship]] to the [[university]] of his choice. The [[Governor#United States|governor]] of each [[U.S. state|state]] and the commissioners of the [[District of Columbia]] were to select a [[high school]] [[Twelfth grade|senior]] to represent their jurisdiction that August at [[Edison National Historic Site|Edison Laboratories]] in [[West Orange, New Jersey]]. Besides Edison, the judges would be [[Henry Ford]], [[Harvey Firestone]], [[George Eastman]], [[Abrahamn De Mallie]], [[Samuel Wesley Stratton|Samuel Stratton]], [[Lewis Perry]] (the [[Principal (school)|principal]] of [[Phillips Exeter Academy]]), and [[Charles Lindbergh]].
Huston's maternal grandfather wrote to his father saying that the contest would be an excellent opportunity. Huston submitted a letter of application, his [[high school]] transcript, and three letters of recommendation. In due course [[Governor#United States|Governor]] [[Roland H. Hartley]] announced that he had selected Huston and four others to travel to the state capital at their own expense for further screening. In [[Olympia, Washington|Olympia]] the candidates took a written examination and submitted to interviews. After a [[caucus]] the examiners recommended that Huston represent [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]].
In August 1929 Huston was in [[West Orange, New Jersey]], to compete for the Edison scholarship. He finished in a five-way tie for first place; the tie was broken by interviews with the judges.
Huston entered [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in the fall of 1929 and graduated in June 1933 with an [[Bachelor of Science|S.B.]] degree in [[physics]]. Following graduation he accepted a position at [[Calibron]], a small research company founded by [[Theodore Edison]], the inventor's youngest son.
In the late 1930s Huston became interested in the [[Moral Re-Armament]] movement and left Calibron to accept a full-time position under [[Frank N. D. Buchman|Frank Buchman]].
As a volunteer religious worker Huston was deferred from the draft until 1943. From that year until late 1944 he served in the [[United States Army Air Forces]] training [[bomber]] crews in [[celestial navigation]] before they went overseas.
In November 1944 the Army transferred Huston to the [[Civilian Reserve Corps]] at the [[Langley Research Center]] in [[Hampton, Virginia]], where he worked as an aeronautical research scientist for the [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics]]. Following his discharge he accepted a [[Civil service#The United States civil service|civil service]] position with [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics|NACA]] at [[Langley Research Center|Langley]].
On July 29, 1958, [[National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics|NACA]] became reconstituted as the [[NASA|National Aeronautics and Space Administration]] with [[Project Mercury]] initially at [[Langley Research Center|Langley]]. Huston provided training for the Mercury [[astronauts]] in [[celestial navigation]].
In 1961 Huston accepted an invitation to transfer to the newly opened [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] to work on the [[Nimbus program]]. As deputy project manager he served as Mission Director for the successful launches of Nimbus 1, launched August 28, 1964, Nimbus 2 on May 15, 1966, Nimbus 3 on May 14, 1969, Nimbus 4 on April 8, 1970, Landsat 1 on July 23, 1972, and Nimbus 5 on December 11, 1972. A Nimbus satellite launched in 1968 failed to reach orbit.
Huston retired from [[NASA]] in 1975 and immediately took a position with OAO Corporation, later part of [[Lockheed Martin Information Technology]]. In 1983 he retired from OAO and became [[Self-employment|self-employed]] until 1988 when he retired for a third and final time.
On September 21, 1946, Huston had married Dorothy E. Beadle (1922 – 1996), a [[mathematician]] at [[Langley Research Center]]. They were the parents of six children, five of whom survived them.
Huston died in [[Fountain Hills, Arizona]], and is buried at [[Holy Trinity Episcopal Church (Bowie, Maryland)|Holy Trinity Episcopal Church]] in [[Bowie, Maryland]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Wilber Huston, 93, Dies; 'Brightest Boy' in 1929 |quote=Wilber B. Huston, whose selection by Thomas A. Edison as the nation's "brightest boy" in 1929 launched him into the intellectual stratosphere but eventually gave him a solid career on the ground as a rocket scientist for NASA, died on May 25 in [[Fountain Hills, Arizona]]. He was 93. |publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=June 10, 2006 }}</ref>

[[Forensic chemistry]] |years_active = |education = University of Edinburgh |work_institutions = [[Medical College and Hospital, Kolkata]] |prizes = Fellow of the Royal Society |relations = |signature = }} '''William Brooke O'Shaughnessy''' (from 1861 as '''William O'Shaughnessy Brooke''') MD [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (October 1809, [[Limerick]], Ireland – 8 January 1889,{{cite journal| title=William O'Shaughnessy - an innovator and entrepreneur| author=Ghose, Saroj| journal=Indian Journal of History of Science| volume=29| issue=1| year=1994| pages= 9–22|url=http://insa.nic.in/writereaddata/UpLoadedFiles/IJHS/Vol29_1_2_SGhose.pdf}} Southsea, England) was an Irish physician famous for his wide-ranging scientific work in pharmacology, chemistry, and inventions related to [[telegraphy]] and its use in India. His medical research led to the development of [[intravenous therapy]] and introduced the [[medical cannabis|therapeutic use]] of ''[[Cannabis sativa]]'' to Western medicine. ==Early life== O'Shaughnessy was born at Limerick in 1809 to Daniel O'Shaughnessy and Sarah Boswell. Many in the family were clergymen, an uncle was the Dean of Ennis and a great uncle the Roman Catholic Bishop of Killaloe. William studied briefly at Trinity College, Dublin matriculating in 1825 but moved to Scotland before graduating. O'Shaughnessy studied [[forensic toxicology]] and [[chemistry]] in Scotland, and graduated in 1829 with an MD from the [[University of Edinburgh Medical School]]. In 1829 he was a clinical assistant of [[William Alison]]. In 1831, at the age of 22, as a result of his analysis of the blood of cholera victims, O'Shaughnessy laid the foundation, along with [[Thomas Latta|Thomas Aitchison Latta]], for what was to become [[Intravenous therapy|intravenous fluid and electrolyte-replacement therapy]] in the treatment of cholera.{{cite journal|author=Moon, J. B. |year=1967|title=Sir William Brooke O'Shaughnessy: The foundations of fluid therapy and the Indian telegraph service| journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=276|issue=5|pages=283–284|doi=10.1056/NEJM196702022760509}} O'Shaughnessy analyzed the urine and blood of cholera patients and came to the conclusion that oxygen in the blood could reverse the actions. He found the blood deficient in water, salt, and "free alkali" and suggested that injecting salts would help. The method used by O'Shaughnessy on a dog and was developed further by Latta.{{cite book|author=Rylah, Lindsey T. A. |year=1992|title=Critical Care of the Burned Patient| publisher= Cambridge University Press|isbn= 0521394953|pages= 2–3}}{{cite book|title= Report on the chemical pathology of the malignant cholera : containing analyses of the blood, dejections, &c. of patients labouring under that disease in Newcastle and London, &c. &c. &c.|author= O'Shaughnessy, William Brooke| year= 1832 | place= London| publisher=S. Highley|url=https://archive.org/details/b22334671 }}{{cite journal|author=Cosnett, J. E. |year=1992| title= Dr. William Brooke O'Shaughnessy| journal=The Old Limerick Journal| volume= 29| pages= 13–16| url= http://www.limerickcity.ie/media/dr%20william%20brooke%20o%27shaughnessy.pdf}}[[Tod H. Mikuriya|Mikuriya, Tod H., MD]], Marijuana Medical Papers, 1839-1972 O'Shaughnessy failed to obtain a position Professor of Medical Jurisprudence in the University of London and his first marriage forced him to join the service of the [[British East India Company]] on 8 August 1833 and he moved to [[Calcutta]], remaining in [[India]] and serving initially at Gyah and Cuttack before joining the 72nd Bengal Native Infantry. He joined the 10th Regiment Bengal Light Cavalry in 1835 and was an assistant to the Opium Agent in Bihar till 5 August 1835 when he became Professor of the [[Medical College and Hospital, Kolkata|medical college]] in Calcutta. He served on the committee of the Materia Medica until 1840 and later was Chemical Examiner to the government. As chemical examiner he developed methods for forensic studies for detecting arsenic poisoning as well as botanical toxins (such as from ''[[Plumbago]]'' used as an abortifacient{{Cite journal|title= Sir William Brooke O'Shaughnessy, F.R.S. (1809-1889), Anglo-Indian Forensic Chemist| author=Gorman, Mel| journal=Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London| volume=39| issue= 1 |year=1984| pages=51–64| jstor=531575| doi=10.1098/rsnr.1984.0004}}).{{cite journal|doi=10.1021/ed046p99|title=Sir William Brooke O'Shaughnessy: Pioneer chemist in a colonial environment|journal=Journal of Chemical Education|volume=46|issue=2|pages=99|year=1969|last1=Gorman|first1=Mel}} He went on furlough to England in 1841 to 1844 and returned to join as Chemical Examiner and additionally as Deputy Assay Master of the Calcutta Mint.{{cite book| title=Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 42|chapter = O'Shaughnessy, William Brooke| author=Pollard, Albert Frederick |pages=310–311 |url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/O%27Shaughnessy,_William_Brooke_(DNB00) }} ==Work in India== [[File:W_B_OShaughnessy.jpg|thumb|left|Portrait by [[Colesworthey Grant]]]] His first stint in India was marked by work in the subjects of botanical pharmacology, chemistry, [[galvanization|galvanic electricity]], and underwater [[electrical conduction|conduction]], among others. He worked on modifications to the Daniell cell and the use of tanned leather semi-permeable membranes in them. He identified the use of zinc to reduce the rusting of iron before the process of galvanizing had been established. O'Shaughnessy also analyzed the gun-cotton developed by [[Christian Friedrich Schönbein]] and recognized the role of nitrogen and correctly identified the role of sulphuric acid in removing water from the cotton. He also developed a silver chloride electrode and experimented on adding colour tones to the Daguerre photographic process.{{Cite journal|last=Thomas|first=G.|date=1986-04-01|title=O'Shaughnessy's experiments in colour photography|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/03087298.1986.10443104|journal=History of Photography|volume=10|issue=2|pages=169–170|doi=10.1080/03087298.1986.10443104|issn=0308-7298}} At [[Calcutta]], he was a member of the [[Medical and Physical Society of Calcutta]], where he published one of his first papers on medical applications of [[cannabis (drug)|cannabis]].{{cite journal|author=O'Shaughnessy, W.B. | title=Case of Tetanus, Cured by a Preparation of Hemp (the Cannabis indica.)| journal=Transactions of the Medical and Physical Society of Bengal| volume= 8|year=1838–40|pages= 462–469}} He validated folk uses of cannabis in India, discovered new applications, and ultimately recommended cannabis for a great variety of therapeutic purposes. O'Shaughnessy established his reputation by successfully relieving the pain of rheumatism and stilling the convulsions of an infant with cannabis. He eventually popularized its use back in England. His most famous success came when he quelled the wrenching muscle spasm of tetanus and rabies with resin. While he could not cure tetanus, he observed that the cannabis mixture reduced their symptoms of [[spasticity]] and their suffering. In 1837 he published his independent design of an electric motor.{{cite journal|author= O'Shaughnessy, W.B. |title=On the employment of the Electromagnet...| journal=Journal of the Calcutta Medical and Physical Society| volume=1| year=1837| pages=27–40, 108–110}}{{cite journal|author=Gorman, Mel| journal= Technology and Culture| volume=9 | issue=2| year=1968| pages= 184–190| title= An Early Electric Motor in India| jstor=3102151 }} In 1839, O'Shaughnessy conducted experiments on an experimental telegraphy system that he set up in the Botanical Garden at Calcutta with the assistance of [[Nathaniel Wallich]]. A length of 22 miles of wire was laid by zigzagging them over bamboo posts.{{cite journal|url=https://archive.org/stream/journalofasiatic08asia#page/714/mode/2up/|pages=714–731| year= 1839| title=Memoranda relative to experiments on the communication of telegraphic signals by induced electricity| author=O'Shaughnessy, W.B.|journal=Journal of the Asiatic Society of Bengal| volume=8}} In 1841, he returned to England where he introduced ''[[Cannabis indica]]'' to Western medicine and continued his scientific writings.{{cite journal|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2490264/pdf/provmedsurgj00865-0001.pdf| year =1843| title=On the preparations of the Indian hemp, or Gunjah, (Cannabis Indica) | author=O'Shaughness, W.B.| issue=123 |pages=1–7| pmc=2490264| volume=5| journal=Prov Med J Retrosp Med Sci}} He was a member of the [[London Electrical Society]] and was elected a [[fellow of the Royal Society]] on 16 March 1843. The Candidature for Election to Fellow of the Royal Society stated that he was "distinguished for his acquaintance with the science of Medicine and Chemistry, eminent as a Physician and as a promoter of education among the natives of Bengal". O'Shaughnessy was a supporter of the idea of education in native languages in medicine. He also wanted locally available sources of medicine to be utilized to provide inexpensive aid. As a teacher, he took students on field trips to the Botanical Garden to introduce them to the local medicinal plants. In 1837 he prepared a ''Manual of Chemistry'' of which a thousand copies were printed for use in Calcutta. A second edition was produced in 1842. Another major book was the ''Bengal Dispensatory and Pharmacopeia'' which included an appendix on the "improvement of Bengal pottery" (1840) since earthenware imports from Europe were proving to be expensive. The ''Bengal Dispensatory'' included descriptions of several plant species that were made or overseen by Wallich including those of ''Abelmoschus longifolius'', ''Pharbitis caerulea'', ''Hebradendron pictorium'' and ''Garcinia pictoria''.{{cite journal|title= The contribution of Sir William Brooke O’Shaughnessy (1809–1889) to plant taxonomy| journal=Phytotaxa| volume=15| year=2011| pages=57–63| author=Turner, I.M.}} These descriptions have often been overlooked by botanists in the past.{{cite journal|title=Sir William Brooke O'Shaughnessy, M.D., F.R.S., F.R.C.S., F.S.A.: A Biographical Appreciation by an Electrical Engineer| author=Bridge, J.A.| journal=Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London| volume=52| issue=1| year=1998| pages=103–120| jstor=532080| doi=10.1098/rsnr.1998.0038}}{{cite book|authorlink=Martin A. Lee|author=Lee, Martin|year= 2012| title= Smoke Signals: A Social History of Marijuana - Medical, Recreational and Scientific''|publisher= Simon and Schuster|isbn= 1439102600|pages= 23–25}} ==Return to India== In 1844, O'Shaughnessy returned to India where he worked in various government positions in the fields of pharmacology and assay. [[James Broun-Ramsay, 1st Marquess of Dalhousie|Lord Dalhousie]] became interested in the establishment of a telegraphic network and he learnt of the work of O'Shaugnessy and found that he could work on the scheme. Dalhousie informed the Military Board that O'Shaugnessy was to work directly under Dalhousie's supervision and report directly without any other intermediary authorities. During this period he began work on various telegraph instruments and systems.{{cite journal|doi=10.1177/0967772015596276 |title= Sir William Brooke O’Shaughnessy (1808–1889), MD, FRS, LRCS Ed: Chemical pathologist, pharmacologist and pioneer in electric telegraphy|author=MacGillivray, Neil| journal=Journal of Medical Biography |year=2015|volume=25|pages=186–196}} After briefly returning to England in 1852, O'Shaughnessy was appointed Superintendent of Telegraphs in 1852. During the years 1853-5 3500 miles of telegraph were installed across India and he wrote numerous manuals and reports on his telegraph inventions. O'Shaughnessy was on leave in England during the mutiny year but in the same year Morse code was introduced into India and a message from Delhi to Punjab helped in moving troops in time. In 1858 a cable was laid in the Gulf of Mannar between India and Ceylon. O'Shaughnessy introduced a coil of fine wire in the circuit to protect the cables from lightning.{{cite book|title= Memoir of Surgeon-Major Sir W. O'Shaughnessy Brooke in connection with the early history of the telegraph in India|author=Adams, M| year=1889| place=Simla| publisher= Government Central Printing Office|url=https://archive.org/details/memoirofsurgeonm00adamrich}}{{cite journal| title=Sir William O'Shaughnessy, Lord Dalhousie, and the Establishment of the Telegraph System in India| author=Gorman, Mel| journal=Technology and Culture| volume=12| issue=4| year= 1971| pages=581–601 | jstor=3102572}} His successor in the telegraphs department, Charles Adley, became a fierce critic of O'Shaughnessy's work. ==Knighthood and return to England== In 1856 he was [[knight]]ed by [[Victoria of the United Kingdom|Queen Victoria]] for his work on the telegraph in India. He was appointed Director-General of Telegraphs at this time. During the following years O'Shaughnessy wrote on telegraphy-related subjects, including a book of Private Codes for [[encrypted]] telegraphy. In 1860, O'Shaughnessy returned to Europe for sick leave where he remained in obscurity until his death from senile asthenia at Southsea on 8 January 1889. He was buried at Highland Road Cemetery, Portsmouth. He adopted the surname Brooke by Royal Licence in 1861 on the death of a relative. He was married twice. His second wife was the daughter of Francis O'Shaughnessy and his third was Julia Greenly, daughter of Captain Sabine.{{cite journal| journal= The British Medical Journal|year=1889|title=Obituary. Sir William O'Shaughnessy Brooke|page=164|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2154565/pdf/brmedj04319-0052a.pdf|volume=1|issue=1464|pmc=2154565|doi=10.1136/bmj.1.1464.164}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://publicdomainreview.org/2017/04/19/w-b-oshaughnessy-and-the-introduction-of-cannabis-to-modern-western-medicine W. B.
